column1: Tanveer “Tan” Wasim Safdar was born and raised in [[Doncaster, South Yorkshire]], England, to Muslim [[Pakistani]] parents.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title='Queer Eye' Star Says Getting Dumped Helped Launch His Career
column8: accessdate=20 February 2018}}</ref> France was raised in a very strict [[Muslims
column9: Muslim]] household where homosexuality was  viewed negatively in his upbringing. \"The word gay was never mentioned in my parents' home\". France discussed how the lack of representation in media and everyday life by his community and specifically LGBTQ south Asian people caused alienation. France’s interest in fashion began at a young age, inspired by the [[Disney]] clothing that was made in his grandparents' [[denim]] factory in Bury, England.<ref name=\"herald\" /><ref name=\"omika\">{{cite web
column11: title=An interview with Tan Safdar, Owner and Designer at Kingdom & State
column15: accessdate=8 March 2018}}</ref>  By age thirteen, he had learned how to construct and embellish a denim jacket; in 2019, he learned his grandfather had to close the factory due to the products being Disney [[knockoffs]].<ref>Interview, Wednesday, 06 January 2020 episode with [[Jane Fonda]]; [[The Late Show With Stephen Colbert]].</ref> He attended [[Hall Cross School]] and later [[Doncaster College]] where he studied fashion,<ref>{{cite journal
column17: title=Meet the Five Fab Men of Netflix's ''Queer Eye'' Reboot
column22: accessdate=19 February 2018}}</ref> before moving to [[Manchester]], and then to London.<ref name=mic>{{cite journal
column24: title=Tan France on his hopes for a second season of Queer Eye and the thousands of DMs about his hair

column1: After graduating from college, France began working for [[Zara (retailer)
column2: Zara]]<ref name=\"omika\" />, [[Selfridges]] & [[Bershka]], among other retailers, to improve his knowledge of the wholesale business of retail, later progressing to work at [[Chanel]] in order to learn more about manufacturing. \"I wanted to diversify my experience, learning everything from design to delivery to wholesale.\" He became managing director in his early twenties.<ref name=\"herald\" /> France was company director at Shade Clothing before he opened his solo company.<ref name=\"omika\" />

column1: France began working in the United States in 2008 and [[emigrated]] to the US in 2015<ref name=\"mic\" />. In late 2011, France founded a women's clothing line, Kingdom & State<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=19 February 2018}}</ref> which included clothing designed to meet [[Mormons
column6: Mormon]] clothing guidelines. “I wanted to create a brand that you couldn’t tell was modest clothing for Mormons,” France says. “These girls were cute and wanted to be fashionable. I wanted to create a London look for them that just so happened to cover the areas of their bodies they had to cover as Mormon women. And that’s where it took off really well [in Utah], really quickly.”<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Queer Eye's Tan France: 'The word gay was never mentioned in my parents' home'
column13: date=9 March 2019}}</ref>. France's business and brands gained popularity and his designs were purchased by the likes of [[ModCloth]] and [[Forever 21]]<ref>{{Citation
column20: oclc=1105752822}}</ref> France is also a designer and [[Chief executive officer
column21: CEO]] in the 2016-founded Rachel Parcell clothing line, sold at [[Nordstrom]]<ref>{{cite web

column1: In 2019, France appeared in the music video for [[Taylor Swift]]'s song \"[[You Need to Calm Down]]\"<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=An annotated guide to Taylor Swift's star-studded \"You Need to Calm Down\" video
column12: url-status=live}}</ref> and later that year in an interview with the [[ITV (TV network)
column14: This Morning]]'', France disclosed that he had sold all three of his businesses after starting work for [[Netflix]].<ref>{{cite web

column1: Tan currently lives in [[Salt Lake City]], Utah, with his husband, illustrator Rob France.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=How a Muslim immigrant became the breakout 'Queer Eye' star
column7: work=New York Post}}</ref> In June 2018, he stated that he would like to have children with his husband by surrogate.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Queer Eye's Tan France: I will use surrogacy to have children

column1: France has a deep love for cooking and especially baking. He learned how to cook and sew at age nine.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Tan France: ‘I’m a nightmare in the kitchen’

column1: France is currently the fashion expert on the Netflix series ''[[Queer Eye (2018 TV series)
column2: Queer Eye]]'' which premiered in February 2018. The second and third seasons were released in June 2018 and March 2019. In May 2019 it was announced that France would be cohosting the new Netflix series ''[[Next In Fashion]]'' with [[Alexa Chung]].<ref>{{cite web
column3: title='Next In Fashion' Reality Competition Will Bow On Netflix, Offering Designers $250K And Showcase

column8: Episode: \"I'm Making Up for Lost Time\"

column7: title=Next in Fashion: Alexa Chung and Tan France to Host Netflix Show

column3: The Great Celebrity Bake Off for SU2C]]''

column2: \"[[You Need to Calm Down (Taylor Swift song)

column1: France released a memoir, ''Naturally Tan'', in June 2019 through [[St. Martin's Press]].<ref>{{cite book
column6: country=ca}} }}</ref> It is about his experience growing up \"gay in a traditional [[Muslim]] family, as one of the few people of colour in [[Doncaster, England]]\". The memoir starts with Tan's childhood in England where episodes of racism were an everyday occurrence, like having to run back to school to avoid getting beat up by racist thugs. The book follows up with heavy topics such as colorism within the south Asian community and the islamophobia he faced before and after the [[September 11 attacks]]. For more lighthearted episodes of Tan's life he describes his first trip to NYC, how he got involved in fashion, how he secretly and hilariously switched major course and how he fell in love with his husband. He also writes about \"his winding journey of coming of age, finding his voice (and style!), and how he finally came out to his family at the age of 34, revealing that he was happily married to the love of his life: a Mormon cowboy from [[Salt Lake City]].\" <ref>https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/40174034-naturally-tan</ref>

column1: * [https://www.out.com/out-exclusives/2018/5/09/tan-france-sold-fashion-business-and-became-tv-star-35-you-can-too Tan France sold his Fashion Business and Became a TV Star at 35, You Can Too]
* [https://www.stylist.co.uk/fashion/alexa-chung-tan-france-netflix-next-in-fashion-dilemmas-style-tips-what-to-wear/353807 Alexa Chung and Tan France Offer Next In Fashion Style Tips]

* [https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/books/story/2019-07-18/queer-eye-tan-france-naturally-tan Queer Eye’s’ Tan France faced racism as a kid. Then he brushed off bullies and discovered self-love]
* [https://www.scmp.com/lifestyle/fashion-beauty/article/3020655/how-queer-eyes-tan-france-found-self-love-after-facing How a fashion guruTan France found self-love after racism]

column2: map_caption              = Location in Plymouth County in Massachusetts

column1: '''Lakeville''' is a town in [[Plymouth County, Massachusetts
column2: Plymouth County]], [[Massachusetts]], United States. The population was 10,602 at the 2010 census.<ref name=\"Census 2010\">{{Cite web
column4: title=Profile of General Population and Housing Characteristics: 2010 Demographic Profile Data (DP-1): Lakeville town, Plymouth County, Massachusetts

column1: For geographic and demographic information on the village of North Lakeville, please see the article [[North Lakeville, Massachusetts]].
Lakeville was settled in 1717 as a western parish of [[Middleborough, Massachusetts
column2: Middleborough]].  It was incorporated as a separate town in 1853.  The town's name comes from the system of lakes in the town, including [[Assawompset Pond]], [[Great Quittacas Pond]], [[Little Quittacas Pond]], [[Pocksha Pond]], and [[Long Pond (Lakeville, Massachusetts)
column3: Long Pond]].  Long Pond is the source of the [[Acushnet River]], and Assawompsett Pond is the source of the [[Nemasket River]], which feeds the [[Taunton River]]. [[Ocean Spray (cooperative)
column4: Ocean Spray]] is headquartered in Lakeville.  Lakeville is also commonly referred to as \"The Promised Land.\"

column1: According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the town has a total area of {{convert
column12: title=Geographic Identifiers: 2010 Demographic Profile Data (G001): Kingston town, Plymouth County, Massachusetts
column14: accessdate=March 20, 2012}}</ref>  Lakeville is irregularly shaped, bordered by [[Middleborough, Massachusetts
column15: Middleborough]] to the northeast and east, [[Rochester, Massachusetts
column17: Freetown]] to the south and southwest, and [[Berkley, Massachusetts
column19: Taunton]] to the west.  Its borders with Taunton, Berkley and Freetown are also a central section of the western borders of Plymouth County.  Lakeville is roughly at the center of what is considered Southeastern Massachusetts, and is approximately {{convert
column27: mi}} east of [[Providence, Rhode Island]], and {{convert

column1: The town's geography is dominated by its namesake lakes, which are referred to as \"ponds\" in general usage.  In addition to the main bodies of water and their feeder brooks and rivers, there are also several smaller ponds, as well as many brooks and swamps, including the Casual Swamp and the Cedar Swamp, which is protected as a part of the Assonet Cedar Swamp Wildlife Management Area, which is operated by the [[Massachusetts Audubon Society]].  There are also several small conservation areas, four country clubs and two parks, including the Ted Williams Camp, which was once the site of a summer baseball camp run by [[Ted Williams]]. According to \"Lakeville, Massachusetts Gravestone Inscriptions 1711-2003\" by Jean Douillette, there are 31 known cemeteries in Lakeville, or almost 1 per square mile.

The body of [[John Sassamon]], advisor to Governor [[Josiah Winslow]], was discovered beneath the ice of Assawompsett Pond. He was believed to have been murdered, and three Native Americans were arrested. On the testimony of only one witness (contrary to English law, which required the testimony of at least two witnesses in a murder trial), the three were sentenced to death by [[hanging]]. When the sentence was carried out, Tobias, senior counselor to the [[Pokanoket]] sachem [[Metacomet
column2: King Philip]], and a second supposed accomplice died. When the attempt was made to carry out the sentence on the third \"accomplice\" - Tobias's son - the rope broke and he was imprisoned, having first confessed to the killings. His confession is widely believed to have been coerced.

column1: The death of John Sassamon and the subsequent trial and execution of the Native Americans - while not the cause of [[King Philip's War]] and the bloodshed that followed - nonetheless probably contributed to the ardor of the participants.

column5: title=U.S. Census website}}</ref> of 2000, there were 9,821 people, 3,292 households, and 2,659 families residing in the town.  The [[population density]] was 328.4 people per square mile (126.8/km²).  There were 3,662 housing units at an average density of 122.5 per square mile (47.3/km²).  The racial makeup of the town was 97.29% [[White (U.S. Census)
column11: other races]], and 1.16% from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)
column13: Latino]] of any race were 1.06% of the population.

column1: The most common ancestries in Lakeville are: Irish (23.2%), English (20.1%), French (12.9%), Italian (11.9%), Portuguese (11.4%) and French Canadian (10.1%).  3.8% of Lakeville's residents are foreign-born.<ref name=\"city-data.com\">[http://www.city-data.com/city/Lakeville-Massachusetts.html]</ref>
There were 3,292 households out of which 40.0% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 69.7% were [[Marriage
column2: married couples]] living together, 8.0% had a female householder with no husband present, and 19.2% were non-families. 14.7% of all households were made up of individuals and 6.2% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.91 and the average family size was 3.24.

column1: In the town, the population was spread out with 27.4% under the age of 18, 5.7% from 18 to 24, 31.1% from 25 to 44, 24.4% from 45 to 64, and 11.3% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 38 years. For every 100 females, there were 93.9 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 91.1 males.  Of the population 25 years and older in Lakeville, 87.2% have a high school degree or higher.  32.7% of this demographic group has a bachelor's degree or higher.  11% of Lakeville residents 25 years or older have a graduate or professional degree.  The average person's commute to work is 33.8 minutes and 2.6% of the town's population above the age of 25 is unemployed.[http://www.city-data.com/city/Lakeville-Massachusetts.html]

The median income for a household in the town was $70,495, and the median income for a family was $75,838. Males had a median income of $51,321 versus $31,374 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the town was $26,046.  About 1.9% of families and 3.0% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 2.8% of those under age 18 and 8.5% of those age 65 or over.
Lakeville's median household income and the medium house value are above the Massachusetts state average.<ref name=\"city-data.com\"/>

Lakeville is governed with the [[Open Town Meeting]] form of government, and is led by a town administrator and a [[board of selectmen]].  The town has its own police department and a single [[fire station]], located next to the town hall.  The \"new\" library is located behind the old town hall, just across Route 18 from its former location at the junction of Routes 18 and 105.  The town of Lakeville also has other services, such as a Council on Aging and a historical commission.

On the state level, Lakeville is represented in the [[Massachusetts House of Representatives]] as a part of the Twelfth Bristol District.  The town is represented by Senator [[Michael J. Rodrigues]] (D-Westport), as a part of the First Bristol and Plymouth District, which also includes Fall River, Freetown, Rochester, Somerset, Swansea and Westport.<ref>[http://www.mass.gov/legis/citytown.htm Index of Legislative Representation by City and Town, from Mass.gov]</ref><ref>[http://www.mass.gov/?pageID=eopsterminal&L=5&L0=Home&L1=Law+Enforcement+%26+Criminal+Justice&L2=Law+Enforcement&L3=State+Police+Troops&L4=Troop+D&sid=Eeops&b=terminalcontent&f=msp_divisions_field_services_troops_troop_d_msp_field_troop_d_station_d4&csid=Eeops Station D-4, SP Middleborough]</ref>

On the national level, Lakeville is a part of [[Massachusetts's 4th congressional district]], and is currently represented by [[Joseph P. Kennedy III]].  The state's senior ([[Classes of United States Senators#Class I
column2: Class I]]) member of the [[United States Senate]], elected in 2012, is [[Elizabeth Warren]]. The junior ([[Classes of United States Senators#Class I
column3: Class II]]) senator, elected in 2013, is [[Ed Markey]].

column1: Since 1959, Lakeville has shared its school department with Freetown, creating the Freetown - Lakeville Regional School District. Lakeville operates several schools for its school aged population.  [[Assawompsett Elementary School]] is operated jointly with [[Freetown, Massachusetts
column2: Freetown]] for grades K-3.  The [[George R. Austin Intermediate School]] is operated jointly with [[Freetown, Massachusetts
column3: Freetown]] for grade 4 and 5.  [[Freetown-Lakeville Middle School]] is operated jointly with Freetown for grades 6-8, and [[Apponequet Regional High School]] is jointly operated with Freetown for grades 9-12.  Apponequet's colors are navy, white, and red, their nickname is the \"Lakers,\" and their mascot was a [[Wampanoag people
column4: Wampanoag]] brave, but after a sensitivity issue among the faculty at Apponequet, it was changed to an \"A\".  The school, like several others in the region, used to use the spear logo made famous by [[Florida State University]] and the [[Washington Redskins]] for its athletics marks, but this was deemed to promote violence, so it was replaced with the \"A\".  Their teams compete in the South Coast Conference, and their chief rival is Old Rochester Regional High School in Mattapoisett.

column1: [[Massachusetts Route 140]], a four-lane divided highway, passes through the town on its trip between [[Massachusetts Route 24
column5: New Bedford]].  The town is also crossed by [[Massachusetts Route 18
column8: Route 105]], as well as a short, {{convert
column11: adj=on}} stretch of [[U.S. Route 44]] in the far northern point of town.  Route 79's eastern terminus is at its intersection with Route 105 on the town line.  Additionally, three exits of [[Interstate 495 (Massachusetts)
column12: Interstate 495]] are located just over the town line in [[Middleborough, Massachusetts
column13: Middleborough]], granting access to Routes 44, 18 and 105 (from north to south in order).

column1: In addition to its highways, the terminus of the Middleborough-Lakeville Line of the [[Massachusetts Bay Transportation Authority
column2: MBTA's]] commuter rail is along the town's border (the rail itself passes along the town line; the parking lots are entirely within Lakeville).  There is also a spur off that line, heading due west to Taunton, which is operated by [[CSX Transportation]].  This spur links the two main lines of the railroad in southeastern Massachusetts; the easternmost heads to [[Cape Cod]] via the line used by the MBTA, and the westernmost proceeds to split in Taunton, sending two lines towards [[Fall River, Massachusetts
column3: Fall River]] and New Bedford, respectively.  The New Bedford line also passes through the town on its west side.  The town has no air facilities of its own.  The nearest private airfield is in Taunton; the nearest regional airport is in New Bedford, and the nearest national and international airport is [[T. F. Green Airport]] in [[Warwick, Rhode Island]].

column1: '''Lakeville''' is a town in [[Plymouth County, Massachusetts
column2: Plymouth County]], [[Massachusetts]], United States. The population was 10,602 at the 2010 census.<ref name=\"Census 2010\">{{Cite web
column4: title=Profile of General Population and Housing Characteristics: 2010 Demographic Profile Data (DP-1): Lakeville town, Plymouth County, Massachusetts

column1: For geographic and demographic information on the village of North Lakeville, please see the article [[North Lakeville, Massachusetts]].
Lakeville was settled in 1717 as a western parish of [[Middleborough, Massachusetts
column2: Middleborough]].  It was incorporated as a separate town in 1853.  The town's name comes from the system of lakes in the town, including [[Assawompset Pond]], [[Great Quittacas Pond]], [[Little Quittacas Pond]], [[Pocksha Pond]], and [[Long Pond (Lakeville, Massachusetts)
column3: Long Pond]].  Long Pond is the source of the [[Acushnet River]], and Assawompsett Pond is the source of the [[Nemasket River]], which feeds the [[Taunton River]]. [[Ocean Spray (cooperative)
column4: Ocean Spray]] is headquartered in Lakeville.  Lakeville is also commonly referred to as \"The Promised Land.\"

column1: According to the [[United States Census Bureau]], the town has a total area of {{convert
column12: title=Geographic Identifiers: 2010 Demographic Profile Data (G001): Kingston town, Plymouth County, Massachusetts
column14: accessdate=March 20, 2012}}</ref>  Lakeville is irregularly shaped, bordered by [[Middleborough, Massachusetts
column15: Middleborough]] to the northeast and east, [[Rochester, Massachusetts
column17: Freetown]] to the south and southwest, and [[Berkley, Massachusetts
column19: Taunton]] to the west.  Its borders with Taunton, Berkley and Freetown are also a central section of the western borders of Plymouth County.  Lakeville is roughly at the center of what is considered Southeastern Massachusetts, and is approximately {{convert
column27: mi}} east of [[Providence, Rhode Island]], and {{convert

column1: The town's geography is dominated by its namesake lakes, which are referred to as \"ponds\" in general usage.  In addition to the main bodies of water and their feeder brooks and rivers, there are also several smaller ponds, as well as many brooks and swamps, including the Casual Swamp and the Cedar Swamp, which is protected as a part of the Assonet Cedar Swamp Wildlife Management Area, which is operated by the [[Massachusetts Audubon Society]].  There are also several small conservation areas, four country clubs and two parks, including the Ted Williams Camp, which was once the site of a summer baseball camp run by [[Ted Williams]]. According to \"Lakeville, Massachusetts Gravestone Inscriptions 1711-2003\" by Jean Douillette, there are 31 known cemeteries in Lakeville, or almost 1 per square mile.

The body of [[John Sassamon]], advisor to Governor [[Josiah Winslow]], was discovered beneath the ice of Assawompsett Pond. He was believed to have been murdered, and three Native Americans were arrested. On the testimony of only one witness (contrary to English law, which required the testimony of at least two witnesses in a murder trial), the three were sentenced to death by [[hanging]]. When the sentence was carried out, Tobias, senior counselor to the [[Pokanoket]] sachem [[Metacomet
column2: King Philip]], and a second supposed accomplice died. When the attempt was made to carry out the sentence on the third \"accomplice\" - Tobias's son - the rope broke and he was imprisoned, having first confessed to the killings. His confession is widely believed to have been coerced.

column1: The death of John Sassamon and the subsequent trial and execution of the Native Americans - while not the cause of [[King Philip's War]] and the bloodshed that followed - nonetheless probably contributed to the ardor of the participants.

column5: title=U.S. Census website}}</ref> of 2000, there were 9,821 people, 3,292 households, and 2,659 families residing in the town.  The [[population density]] was 328.4 people per square mile (126.8/km²).  There were 3,662 housing units at an average density of 122.5 per square mile (47.3/km²).  The racial makeup of the town was 97.29% [[White (U.S. Census)
column11: other races]], and 1.16% from two or more races. [[Hispanic (U.S. Census)
column13: Latino]] of any race were 1.06% of the population.

column1: The most common ancestries in Lakeville are: Irish (23.2%), English (20.1%), French (12.9%), Italian (11.9%), Portuguese (11.4%) and French Canadian (10.1%).  3.8% of Lakeville's residents are foreign-born.<ref name=\"city-data.com\">[http://www.city-data.com/city/Lakeville-Massachusetts.html]</ref>
There were 3,292 households out of which 40.0% had children under the age of 18 living with them, 69.7% were [[Marriage
column2: married couples]] living together, 8.0% had a female householder with no husband present, and 19.2% were non-families. 14.7% of all households were made up of individuals and 6.2% had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older.  The average household size was 2.91 and the average family size was 3.24.

column1: In the town, the population was spread out with 27.4% under the age of 18, 5.7% from 18 to 24, 31.1% from 25 to 44, 24.4% from 45 to 64, and 11.3% who were 65 years of age or older.  The median age was 38 years. For every 100 females, there were 93.9 males.  For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 91.1 males.  Of the population 25 years and older in Lakeville, 87.2% have a high school degree or higher.  32.7% of this demographic group has a bachelor's degree or higher.  11% of Lakeville residents 25 years or older have a graduate or professional degree.  The average person's commute to work is 33.8 minutes and 2.6% of the town's population above the age of 25 is unemployed.[http://www.city-data.com/city/Lakeville-Massachusetts.html]

The median income for a household in the town was $70,495, and the median income for a family was $75,838. Males had a median income of $51,321 versus $31,374 for females. The [[per capita income]] for the town was $26,046.  About 1.9% of families and 3.0% of the population were below the [[poverty line]], including 2.8% of those under age 18 and 8.5% of those age 65 or over.
Lakeville's median household income and the medium house value are above the Massachusetts state average.<ref name=\"city-data.com\"/>

Lakeville is governed with the [[Open Town Meeting]] form of government, and is led by a town administrator and a [[board of selectmen]].  The town has its own police department and a single [[fire station]], located next to the town hall.  The \"new\" library is located behind the old town hall, just across Route 18 from its former location at the junction of Routes 18 and 105.  The town of Lakeville also has other services, such as a Council on Aging and a historical commission.

On the state level, Lakeville is represented in the [[Massachusetts House of Representatives]] as a part of the Twelfth Bristol District.  The town is represented by Senator [[Michael J. Rodrigues]] (D-Westport), as a part of the First Bristol and Plymouth District, which also includes Fall River, Freetown, Rochester, Somerset, Swansea and Westport.<ref>[http://www.mass.gov/legis/citytown.htm Index of Legislative Representation by City and Town, from Mass.gov]</ref><ref>[http://www.mass.gov/?pageID=eopsterminal&L=5&L0=Home&L1=Law+Enforcement+%26+Criminal+Justice&L2=Law+Enforcement&L3=State+Police+Troops&L4=Troop+D&sid=Eeops&b=terminalcontent&f=msp_divisions_field_services_troops_troop_d_msp_field_troop_d_station_d4&csid=Eeops Station D-4, SP Middleborough]</ref>

On the national level, Lakeville is a part of [[Massachusetts's 4th congressional district]], and is currently represented by [[Joseph P. Kennedy III]].  The state's senior ([[Classes of United States Senators#Class I

column3: Class II]]) senator, elected in 2013, is [[Ed Markey]].

column1: Tanveer “Tan” Wasim Safdar was born and raised in [[Doncaster, South Yorkshire]], England, to Muslim [[Pakistani]] parents.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title='Queer Eye' Star Says Getting Dumped Helped Launch His Career
column8: accessdate=20 February 2018}}</ref> France was raised in a very strict [[Muslims
column9: Muslim]] household where homosexuality was  viewed negatively in his upbringing. \"The word gay was never mentioned in my parents' home\". France discussed how the lack of representation in media and everyday life by his community and specifically LGBTQ south Asian people caused alienation. France’s interest in fashion began at a young age, inspired by the [[Disney]] clothing that was made in his grandparents' [[denim]] factory in Bury, England.<ref name=\"herald\" /><ref name=\"omika\">{{cite web
column11: title=An interview with Tan Safdar, Owner and Designer at Kingdom & State
column15: accessdate=8 March 2018}}</ref>  By age thirteen, he had learned how to construct and embellish a denim jacket; in 2019, he learned his grandfather had to close the factory due to the products being Disney [[knockoffs]].<ref>Interview, Wednesday, 06 January 2020 episode with [[Jane Fonda]]; [[The Late Show With Stephen Colbert]].</ref> He attended [[Hall Cross School]] and later [[Doncaster College]] where he studied fashion,<ref>{{cite journal
column17: title=Meet the Five Fab Men of Netflix's ''Queer Eye'' Reboot
column22: accessdate=19 February 2018}}</ref> before moving to [[Manchester]], and then to London.<ref name=mic>{{cite journal
column24: title=Tan France on his hopes for a second season of Queer Eye and the thousands of DMs about his hair

column1: After graduating from college, France began working for [[Zara (retailer)
column2: Zara]]<ref name=\"omika\" />, [[Selfridges]] & [[Bershka]], among other retailers, to improve his knowledge of the wholesale business of retail, later progressing to work at [[Chanel]] in order to learn more about manufacturing. \"I wanted to diversify my experience, learning everything from design to delivery to wholesale.\" He became managing director in his early twenties.<ref name=\"herald\" /> France was company director at Shade Clothing before he opened his solo company.<ref name=\"omika\" />

column1: France began working in the United States in 2008 and [[emigrated]] to the US in 2015<ref name=\"mic\" />. In late 2011, France founded a women's clothing line, Kingdom & State<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=19 February 2018}}</ref> which included clothing designed to meet [[Mormons
column6: Mormon]] clothing guidelines. “I wanted to create a brand that you couldn’t tell was modest clothing for Mormons,” France says. “These girls were cute and wanted to be fashionable. I wanted to create a London look for them that just so happened to cover the areas of their bodies they had to cover as Mormon women. And that’s where it took off really well [in Utah], really quickly.”<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Queer Eye's Tan France: 'The word gay was never mentioned in my parents' home'
column13: date=9 March 2019}}</ref>. France's business and brands gained popularity and his designs were purchased by the likes of [[ModCloth]] and [[Forever 21]]<ref>{{Citation
column20: oclc=1105752822}}</ref> France is also a designer and [[Chief executive officer
column21: CEO]] in the 2016-founded Rachel Parcell clothing line, sold at [[Nordstrom]]<ref>{{cite web

column3: title=An annotated guide to Taylor Swift's star-studded \"You Need to Calm Down\" video
column12: url-status=live}}</ref> and later that year in an interview with the [[ITV (TV network)
column14: This Morning]]'', France disclosed that he had sold all three of his businesses after starting work for [[Netflix]].<ref>{{cite web

column7: work=New York Post}}</ref> In June 2018, he stated that he would like to have children with his husband by surrogate.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Queer Eye's Tan France: I will use surrogacy to have children

column1: France has a deep love for cooking and especially baking. He learned how to cook and sew at age nine.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Tan France: ‘I’m a nightmare in the kitchen’

column1: France is currently the fashion expert on the Netflix series ''[[Queer Eye (2018 TV series)
column2: Queer Eye]]'' which premiered in February 2018. The second and third seasons were released in June 2018 and March 2019. In May 2019 it was announced that France would be cohosting the new Netflix series ''[[Next In Fashion]]'' with [[Alexa Chung]].<ref>{{cite web
column3: title='Next In Fashion' Reality Competition Will Bow On Netflix, Offering Designers $250K And Showcase

column1: France released a memoir, ''Naturally Tan'', in June 2019 through [[St. Martin's Press]].<ref>{{cite book
column6: country=ca}} }}</ref> It is about his experience growing up \"gay in a traditional [[Muslim]] family, as one of the few people of colour in [[Doncaster, England]]\". The memoir starts with Tan's childhood in England where episodes of racism were an everyday occurrence, like having to run back to school to avoid getting beat up by racist thugs. The book follows up with heavy topics such as colorism within the south Asian community and the islamophobia he faced before and after the [[September 11 attacks]]. For more lighthearted episodes of Tan's life he describes his first trip to NYC, how he got involved in fashion, how he secretly and hilariously switched major course and how he fell in love with his husband. He also writes about \"his winding journey of coming of age, finding his voice (and style!), and how he finally came out to his family at the age of 34, revealing that he was happily married to the love of his life: a Mormon cowboy from [[Salt Lake City]].\" <ref>https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/40174034-naturally-tan</ref>

column47: title='Great British Bake Off' Star Tamal Ray Shares His Coming Out Experience: ‘The Conversations Were Canyons Of Awkwardness, The Freedoms They Gave Me Were Priceless'
column53: title=When \"The Great British Bake Off\" Met \"RuPaul's Drag Race U.K.\"
column56: accessdate=13 April 2020}}</ref>, and [[Sushant Divgikar]] is an openly gay Indian TV personality known for his appearance in [[Bigg Boss]]<ref>{{cite web
column63: language=en}}</ref>}} and the third out gay [[Muslims
column64: Muslim]] man on western television after [[Omar Sharif Jr.]] and [[Haaz Sleiman]],{{efn
column65: Sleiman came out as “a gay, Muslim, Arab American man” in August 2017, with appearances on U.S. & British shows broadcast internationally <ref>{{Cite web
column67: title='Nurse Jackie' Star Comes Out As Gay And A 'Total Bottom'
column76: access-date=April 12, 2020}}</ref>, [[Omar Sharif Jr.]] came out as gay, Jewish, and Muslim in 2012, and has appeared in Films and Television series.<ref>{{Cite web
column78: title=Omar Sharif Jr: I’m gay and Jewish
column87: access-date=April 12, 2020}}</ref>. [[Mawaan Rizwan]] although raised in an Islamic household, now identifies as [[Atheist]]<ref>{{cite web
column90: title=Mawaan Rizwan at Latitude : Reviews 2019 : Chortle : The UK Comedy Guide
column94: language=en}}</ref>}} as the fashion expert for the [[Netflix]] series ''[[Queer Eye (2018 TV series)
column95: Queer Eye]]'', host of the web series ''Dressing Funny'', and co-host of ''[[Next In Fashion]]''.<ref name=\":0\">{{Cite web
column97: title=Books: Tan about town, 'Queer Eye' guru pens new memoir
column111: title=Queer Eye's Tan France: 'The word gay was never mentioned in my parents' home' {{!}} Queer Eye {{!}} The Guardian
column132: title=BOOKS Tan about town, 'Queer Eye' guru pens new memoir - Gay Lesbian Bi Trans News - Windy City Times
column140: access-date=January 6, 2020}}</ref> He also wrote a [[memoir]], ''Naturally Tan''.<ref name=\":0\" />

column1: Tanveer “Tan” Wasim Safdar was born and raised in [[Doncaster, South Yorkshire]], England, to Muslim [[Pakistani]] parents.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title='Queer Eye' Star Says Getting Dumped Helped Launch His Career
column8: accessdate=20 February 2018}}</ref> France was raised in a very strict [[Muslims
column9: Muslim]] household where homosexuality was  viewed negatively in his upbringing. \"The word gay was never mentioned in my parents' home\". France discussed how the lack of representation in media and everyday life by his community and specifically LGBTQ south Asian people caused alienation. France’s interest in fashion began at a young age, inspired by the [[Disney]] clothing that was made in his grandparents' [[denim]] factory in Bury, England.<ref name=\"herald\" /><ref name=\"omika\">{{cite web
column11: title=An interview with Tan Safdar, Owner and Designer at Kingdom & State
column15: accessdate=8 March 2018}}</ref>  By age thirteen, he had learned how to construct and embellish a denim jacket; in 2019, he learned his grandfather had to close the factory due to the products being Disney [[knockoffs]].<ref>Interview, Wednesday, 06 January 2020 episode with [[Jane Fonda]]; [[The Late Show With Stephen Colbert]].</ref> He attended [[Hall Cross School]] and later [[Doncaster College]] where he studied fashion,<ref>{{cite journal
column17: title=Meet the Five Fab Men of Netflix's ''Queer Eye'' Reboot
column22: accessdate=19 February 2018}}</ref> before moving to [[Manchester]], and then to London.<ref name=mic>{{cite journal
column24: title=Tan France on his hopes for a second season of Queer Eye and the thousands of DMs about his hair

column1: After graduating from college, France began working for [[Zara (retailer)
column2: Zara]].<ref name=\"omika\" /> He has also worked for [[Selfridges]], [[Bershka]], among other retailers to learn more about the wholesale business side, and finally [[Chanel]] to learn more about manufacturing. \"I wanted to diversify my experience, learning everything from design to delivery to wholesale.\" He became managing director in his early twenties.<ref name=\"herald\" /> France was company director at Shade Clothing before he opened his solo company.<ref name=\"omika\" />

column1: France started working in the United States in 2008 and moved to the US in 2015.<ref name=\"mic\" /> In late 2011, France founded a women's clothing line, Kingdom & State.<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate=19 February 2018}}</ref> The clothing designed by France includes items that meet [[Mormons
column6: Mormon]] clothing guidelines. “I wanted to create a brand that you couldn’t tell was modest clothing for Mormons,” France says. “These girls were cute and wanted to be fashionable. I wanted to create a London look for them that just so happened to cover the areas of their bodies they had to cover as Mormon women. And that’s where it took off really well [in Utah], really quickly.”<ref>{{cite web
column9: title=Queer Eye's Tan France: 'The word gay was never mentioned in my parents' home'

column1: France's business and brands became so successful his designs were purchased by the likes of [[ModCloth]] and [[Forever 21]].<ref>{{Citation
column8: oclc=1105752822}}</ref> France is also a designer and [[Chief executive officer
column9: CEO]] in the 2016-founded Rachel Parcell clothing line, sold at [[Nordstrom]].<ref>{{cite web

column1: France appeared in the music video for [[Taylor Swift]]'s song \"[[You Need to Calm Down]]\".<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=An annotated guide to Taylor Swift's star-studded \"You Need to Calm Down\" video

column1: In an interview with the [[ITV (TV network)
column2: ITV]] programme ''This Morning'', France said that he had sold all three of his businesses after starting work for [[Netflix]].<ref>{{cite web

column1: Tan currently lives in [[Salt Lake City]], Utah, with his husband, illustrator Rob France.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title=How a Muslim immigrant became the breakout 'Queer Eye' star
column7: work=New York Post}}</ref> In June 2018, he stated that he would like to have children with his husband by surrogate.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=Queer Eye's Tan France: I will use surrogacy to have children

column1: France has a deep love for cooking and especially baking. He learned how to cook and sew at age nine.<ref>{{Cite news
column5: title=Tan France: ‘I’m a nightmare in the kitchen’

column1: France is currently the fashion expert on the Netflix series ''[[Queer Eye (2018 TV series)
column2: Queer Eye]]'' which premiered in February 2018. The second and third seasons were released in June 2018 and March 2019. In May 2019 it was announced that France would be cohosting the new Netflix series ''[[Next In Fashion]]'' with [[Alexa Chung]].<ref>{{cite web
column3: title='Next In Fashion' Reality Competition Will Bow On Netflix, Offering Designers $250K And Showcase

column8: Episode: \"I'm Making Up for Lost Time\"

column7: title=Next in Fashion: Alexa Chung and Tan France to Host Netflix Show

column3: The Great Celebrity Bake Off for SU2C]]''

column2: \"[[You Need to Calm Down (Taylor Swift song)

column1: France released a memoir, ''Naturally Tan'', in June 2019 through [[St. Martin's Press]].<ref>{{cite book
column6: country=ca}} }}</ref> It is about his experience growing up \"gay in a traditional [[Muslim]] family, as one of the few people of colour in [[Doncaster, England]]\". The memoir starts with Tan's childhood in England where episodes of racism were an everyday occurrence, like having to run back to school to avoid getting beat up by racist thugs. The book follows up with heavy topics such as colorism within the south Asian community and the islamophobia he faced before and after the [[September 11 attacks]]. For more lighthearted episodes of Tan's life he describes his first trip to NYC, how he got involved in fashion, how he secretly and hilariously switched major course and how he fell in love with his husband. He also writes about \"his winding journey of coming of age, finding his voice (and style!), and how he finally came out to his family at the age of 34, revealing that he was happily married to the love of his life: a Mormon cowboy from [[Salt Lake City]].\" <ref>https://www.goodreads.com/book/show/40174034-naturally-tan</ref>

column1: * [https://www.out.com/out-exclusives/2018/5/09/tan-france-sold-fashion-business-and-became-tv-star-35-you-can-too Tan France sold his Fashion Business and Became a TV Star at 35, You Can Too]
* [https://www.stylist.co.uk/fashion/alexa-chung-tan-france-netflix-next-in-fashion-dilemmas-style-tips-what-to-wear/353807 Alexa Chung and Tan France Offer Next In Fashion Style Tips]

* [https://www.latimes.com/entertainment-arts/books/story/2019-07-18/queer-eye-tan-france-naturally-tan Queer Eye’s’ Tan France faced racism as a kid. Then he brushed off bullies and discovered self-love]
* [https://www.scmp.com/lifestyle/fashion-beauty/article/3020655/how-queer-eyes-tan-france-found-self-love-after-facing How a fashion guruTan France found self-love after racism]
[[Category:British expatriates in the United States]]",Tan France,//en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tan_France

column1: The international community considers Israeli settlements in the West Bank [[international law and Israeli settlements
column2: illegal under international law]], but the Israeli and United States governments dispute this.<ref name=\"news.bbc.co.uk\">{{cite news

column1: Beitar Illit, (lit. Upper Beitar) is named after the ancient Jewish city of [[Betar (fortress)

column2: ARIJ]], Beitar Illit was established in 1985 on land which Israel had confiscated from two nearby [[Palestinians
column3: Palestinian]] villages: 3,140 [[dunam]]s from [[Husan]]<ref>[http://vprofile.arij.org/bethlehem/pdfs/VP/Husan_vp_en.pdf Husan Village Profile], ARIJ, p. 17</ref> and 1,166 dunams from [[Nahalin]].<ref>[http://vprofile.arij.org/bethlehem/pdfs/VP/Nahhalin_vp_en.pdf Nahhalin Village Profile], ARIJ, p. 18</ref>

column1: It was established by a small group of young families from the [[Religious Zionism
column2: religious Zionist]] [[yeshiva]] of [[Machon Meir]]. The first residents settled in 1990.<ref name=tzoren>Tzoren, Moshe Michael. \"Some Talk Peace, Others Live It\". ''[[Hamodia]]'' Israel News, November 21, 2018, pp. A18-A19.</ref> As Beitar Illit began to grow, an influx of [[Haredi Judaism
column5: Bobover]] families came to predominate, while the original group moved on. The city is now home to many [[Hasidic Judaism
column11: Slonim]]. The city has expanded to three adjacent hills.{{Citation needed

column1: Beitar Illit lies in the northern Judean Hills<ref name=\"govisitisrael1\"/> at about 700 m [[Above mean sea level
column2: above sea level]]. It is located just west of the intersection of [[Highway 60 (Israel–Palestine)
column3: Route 60]], the north–south artery which roughly follows the [[Water divide
column4: watershed]] from [[Nazareth]] through Jerusalem to [[Beersheba]], and Route 375, which descends west into the [[Valley of Elah
column5: Elah Valley]] to the [[Israeli Coastal Plain
column7: Tel Aviv area]]. It takes about 10 minutes to get to [[Jerusalem]]; [[Tel Aviv]] is around 60 minutes away. Beitar Illit is connected to West Jerusalem by the [[Highway 60 (Israel–Palestine)#Bypass roads
column8: Tunnels Highway]], which passes directly underneath the Arab town of [[Beit Jala]] and allows access to Jerusalem without coming within view of Arabs.<ref>{{cite journal

column1: At the end of 2003, the population was 23,000 and in 2006 it was 29,100. According to statistics from the Ministry of the Interior, the population in January 2007 was 35,000, an increase of 20% over one year.<ref name=economy/> A Ministry of Interior report from July 2013 placed the population at 45,710.<ref name=misrad>{{cite web
column3: script-title=he:הודעה בדבר קביעת מספר חברי המועצה במועצות מקומיות
column5: trans-title=Notice Regarding the Assignment of Council Members in Regional Councils

column1: With an annual [[birth rate]] of 1,800 births, Beitar Illit has the fastest [[population growth]] among the West Bank settlements.<ref name=tzoren/> Approximately 63 percent of the population is under the age of 18, which is the highest percentage of children in any Israeli settlement or city.<ref name=tzoren/> According to local authorities the population may reach 100,000 by 2020,<ref>{{cite news
column5: title=Ultra-Orthodox Jews deliver a population boom to the West Bank
column8: access-date=August 22, 2012}}</ref> based on population growth and the building of new apartments to attract more Haredim from [[Bnei Brak]] and [[Jerusalem]].

column1: The population of Beitar Illit is 100% [[Haredi Judaism
column6: access-date=14 December 2013}}</ref> Approximately 50% of the population is [[Hasidic Judaism
column12: access-date=14 December 2013}}</ref> An estimated 10 percent of the population is [[English language
column13: English-speaking]]. There are three English-speaking [[synagogue]]s, two English-speaking [[kollel]]s (one for retirees), and an English-speaking women's group.<ref name=nbn/> All incoming residents used to be screened by an acceptance committee.<ref name=nbn/>

column1: As the population of Beitar Illit is Haredi, the schools are all Haredi schools.<ref name=tzoren/> The city has close to 20,000 schoolchildren. Of these, approximately 6,000 are enrolled in the city's 225 preschools and daycare centers. Elementary school-age boys attend the city's 27 [[Talmud Torah]]s, and elementary school-age girls attend 18 elementary schools. Secondary education includes 21 [[yeshiva]]s for boys and 11 high schools and post-high schools for girls. Married adult men study in 75 [[kollel]]s.<ref name=tzoren/>

A significant number of men work, mostly at home or in Jerusalem. Women are employed by local [[business process outsourcing]] companies that accommodate the Haredi lifestyle, such as Greenpoint, Matrix, and CityBook.<ref name=nbn/> In 2010, it was reported that 64.3% of working-age men and 45.8% of working-age women in Beitar Illit were unemployed.<ref name=economy>{{cite book
column3: title=The Israeli Economy from the Foundation of the State through the 21st Century

column1: One hundred and forty [[synagogue]]s and 15 [[mikveh]]s serve the population.<ref name=tzoren/>

Beitar Illit has been awarded the Israel Ministry of Interior's gold prize, recognizing \"responsible management and sustainable urban planning\", for eight years running.<ref name=tzoren/> In 2002, it received the Ministry of Interior's prize for [[water conservation]] in public gardens, urban public institutions, and urban water administration.<ref name=tzoren/> The municipal welfare department was awarded a prize and recognized by the national government as an \"outstanding department\" for its work in preventing teen [[Dropping out

The city is well known for its landscaping and general cleanliness. There are 94 parks and hundreds of playgrounds in the city.<ref name=tzoren/> From 2000 to 2013, Beitar Illit earned five out of five stars in the [[Council for a Beautiful Israel]]'s annual \"Beautiful Town in a Beautiful Israel\" contest, which recognizes a city's investment in environment, aesthetics, and maintenance of appearance and cleanliness. In 2005 the city won the Council for a Beautiful Israel's \"Beauty Flag\", which is awarded every five years.<ref name=tzoren/>

Like all settlements in the [[Israeli-occupied territories]], Beitar Illit is considered illegal under international law,<ref name=\"Agence France-Presse\"/><ref name=\"docs.newsbank.com\"/> though Israel disputes this while the [[Presidency of Donald Trump
column2: Trump Administration]] in November 2019 shifted its position<ref>{{Cite news
column4: title=Jewish settlements no longer illegal - US
column7: language=en-GB}}</ref> declaring \"the establishment of Israeli civilian settlements in the West Bank is not ''per se'' inconsistent with international law.\"<ref>{{Cite web
column9: title=Secretary of State Mike Pompeo announces reversal of Obama-era stance on Israeli settlements
column12: access-date=2019-11-18}}</ref> The international community considers Israeli settlements to violate the [[Fourth Geneva Convention]]'s prohibition on the transfer of an occupying power's civilian population into occupied territory. The Israeli government disputes that the Fourth Geneva Convention applies to the Palestinian territories as they had not been legally held by a sovereign prior to Israel taking control of them.<ref name=\"BBC_GC4\"/> This view has been rejected by the [[International Court of Justice]] and the [[International Committee of the Red Cross]].<ref>[http://www.icj-cij.org/docket/files/131/1671.pdf Legal Consequences of the Construction of a Wall in the Occupied Palestinian Territory] {{webarchive
column14: date=2010-07-06 }} International Court of Justice, 9 July 2004. pp. 44-45</ref>

column1: At an international conference in Karlsruhe in November 2010, Jawad Hasan claimed that sewage and urban runoff from Beitar Illit have contaminated the local hydrological system.<ref>{{cite book
column5: title=Integrated water resources management Karlsruhe 2010 : international conference, 24 - 25 November 2010; conference proceedings
column12: chapter=Watershed Management Under Terms of Depletive Water Balance and High Vulnerability in Wadi Fuqeen: West Bank Palestine}}</ref> The [[Palestinian Authority]] claims that sewage flows into neighboring Palestinian fields and orchards.<ref name=wafa>{{cite news
column13: title=Settlers Drown Palestinians' Land with Wastewater in Bethlehem
column20: archive-date=1 June 2011 }}</ref> Farmers from [[Wadi Fukin]] have complained that since the establishment of Beitar Illit in 1985, 11 natural wells have gone dry and they have suffered from overflow from the settlement's backed up sewers. The Israeli government has ordered Beitar Illit to address these sewage problems.<ref name=partnership>{{cite news
column22: title=Palestinian village and Israeli town build rare partnership across line
column23: publisher=Jewish Journal of Greater Los Angeles

column1: In 2010, the Israeli interior ministry announced plans to build 112 new apartments during a visit by U.S. vice-president [[Joe Biden]], leading to widespread news coverage that embarrassed the Israeli government.<ref>{{cite news
column2: title= Israel sorry for announcing homes plan during Biden visit

column1: Beitar Illit was one of four cities named in a petition to the [[Israeli High Court]] in December 2010 alleging a pattern of discrimination against [[Sephardi]] girls in the local Haredi schools. A Beitar Illit spokesman denied the charges, stating that the percentage of Sephardi girls in the school matched the percentage of Sephardim in the settlement.<ref>{{cite news
column2: title=Court postpones ruling on haredi school discrimination petition

column20: archive-date=1 June 2011 }}</ref> Farmers from [[Wadi Fukin]] have complained that since the establishment of Beitar Illit in 1985, 11 natural wells have gone dry and they have suffered from overflow from the settlement's backed up sewers. The Israeli government has ordered Beitar Illit to address these sewage problems.<ref name=partnership>{{cite news
column22: title=Palestinian village and Israeli town build rare partnership across line
column23: publisher=Jewish Journal of Greater Los Angeles

column1: In 2010, the Israeli interior ministry announced plans to build 112 new apartments during a visit by U.S. vice-president [[Joe Biden]], leading to widespread news coverage that embarrassed the Israeli government.<ref>{{cite news
column2: title= Israel sorry for announcing homes plan during Biden visit

column1: Beitar Illit was one of four cities named in a petition to the [[Israeli High Court]] in December 2010 alleging a pattern of discrimination against [[Sephardi]] girls in the local Haredi schools. A Beitar Illit spokesman denied the charges, stating that the percentage of Sephardi girls in the school matched the percentage of Sephardim in the settlement.<ref>{{cite news
column2: title=Court postpones ruling on haredi school discrimination petition

column1: * [[Rivka Ravitz]], chief of staff to [[President of Israel]] [[Reuven Rivlin]]
* [[Battir]], an Arab village adjacent to Beitar Illit and the Betar ruins.
* [[Betar (fortress)]], the last Jewish fort held in the [[Bar Kochba revolt]]
* [[List of Israeli settlements with city status in the West Bank]]
* [http://www.betarelit.net/ Haredi news website for Beitar Illit]

column5: title=In West Bank Settlements, Sign of Hope for a Deal

column1: The '''1998 United States Capitol shooting incident''' was an attack on July 24, 1998, which led to the deaths of two [[United States Capitol Police]] officers. Officer [[Jacob Chestnut]] and Detective [[John Gibson (police officer)
column2: John Gibson]] were killed when Russell Eugene Weston, Jr., entered the [[United States Capitol
column3: Capitol]] and opened fire.<ref name=CNN>{{cite news
column5: title = 2 dead, 2 hurt in U.S. Capitol shooting
column9: archivedate = October 29, 2006}}</ref> Chestnut was killed instantly and Gibson died during surgery at [[George Washington University Hospital]]. Weston's exact motives are unknown, but he has a [[mental disorder]] and maintains a strong distrust of the [[Federal Government of the United States
column10: federal government of the United States]]. He remains in a mental institution due to [[paranoid schizophrenia]] and has yet to be tried in court.

column1: On the day of the shooting, Officer Chestnut and an unarmed, civilian security aide were assigned to operate the X-ray machine and magnetometer at the Document Door entrance located on the East Front of the Capitol, which was open only to [[Member of Congress
column2: Members of Congress]] and their staff. Detective Gibson was assigned to the dignitary protection detail of Rep. Tom DeLay (R-TX) and was in his suite of offices near this door. Weston, armed with a [[.38 S&W
column3: .38 caliber]] [[Smith & Wesson]] six-shot revolver, entered the Document Door at 3:40 p.m. At the same time, Officer Chestnut was providing directions to a tourist and his son.<ref name=buried/> Weston walked through the [[metal detector]],  causing the alarm to go off. Chestnut requested he go back through the detector.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title = Gunman Shoots His Way Into Capitol; Two Officers Killed, Suspect Captured
column8: date=January 30, 1999}}</ref> Weston suddenly produced the gun and without warning, shot Chestnut in the back of the head at point-blank range.  At this time, Officer Douglas McMillan, normally working outside the Capitol, was nearby retrieving keys to get a wheelchair for a tourist. As Weston shot Officer Chestnut, Officer McMillan immediately returned fire, causing Weston to shoot toward McMillan. Weston then ran away from McMillan, turning into the first nearby open door that he found. Unfortunately, Officer McMillan was unable to successfully hit Weston, due to the many civilians in the immediate area.  According to witnesses, Weston turned down a short corridor and pushed through a door which leads to a group of offices used by senior Republican representatives including then [[Party whips of the United States House of Representatives
column9: Majority Whip]] [[Tom DeLay]] and Representative [[Dennis Hastert]], future [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives
column10: Speaker of the House]] and a close [[Mentorship
column11: protégé]] of then [[Speaker of the United States House of Representatives

column1: Upon hearing the gunfire, Detective Gibson, who was in plainclothes, told the office staff to hide under their desks. Within seconds, Gibson was shot after the suspect entered DeLay's office. Despite being mortally wounded, Detective Gibson was able to return fire,  and wound the suspect hitting him with 4 rounds, severely wounding him and causing him to be apprehended in that office by Officer Vincent Farri and Sergeant John Planchart.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title = Capitol Hill Slayings: The Overview; Gunman Invades Capitol, Killing 2 Guards
column8: date=July 25, 1998}}</ref> A female tourist was grazed by shrapnel on her face and shoulder, from a marble wall, as Officer McMillan's rounds impacted on the wall, while he was attempting to hit the fleeing Weston.<ref>[http://www.findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qn4196/is_19980726/ai_n10434376 \"Horrifying Capitol ordeal began with officer's execution\"]. (July 26, 1998). Milwaukee Journal Sentinel, The.</ref> She was treated for her injuries and released.<ref name=\"Yehle 1, 18\">{{cite news
column18: date= April 16, 2008 }}</ref> Future Senate Majority Leader [[Bill Frist]], R-Tennessee, a heart surgeon who had been presiding on the Senate floor just before the shooting, resuscitated the gunman and accompanied him to [[D.C. General Hospital]].<ref name=\"CNN\" />

column4: A Capitol Police Honor Guard salutes the coffins of Officer Jacob Chestnut and Detective John Gibson in the Capitol Rotunda as they lie in repose]]

column1: Officers Chestnut and Gibson were the two people killed in the attack. Following the shooting, both officers received the tribute of [[lying in honor]] in the [[United States Capitol rotunda]]. They were the first police officers, and Chestnut was the first male [[African American]], to receive the honor.<ref>{{cite web
column3: title = Authorizing the use of the Rotunda of the Capitol...

column1: In 1999, Weston was found incompetent to stand trial due to mental illness as he was a man with [[schizophrenia]] who stopped taking his medication.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title = Weston found incompetent to stand trial for Capitol shooting
column7: last=Frieden}}</ref> A judge of the [[United States District Court for the District of Columbia]] ordered that he be treated with [[antipsychotic drugs
column8: antipsychotic medication]] without his consent in 2001, and the [[United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit]] upheld the decision.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title=Capitol Shooter Russell Weston, Three Years Later
column15: archivedate=November 28, 2006 }}</ref> In 2004, the court determined that Weston still was not competent to be tried, despite ongoing treatment, and suspended but did not dismiss the [[Criminal law
column16: criminal]] charges against him. Weston was known to the [[United States Secret Service]] prior to the incident as a person who had threatened the President of the United States.<ref>{{cite news
column18: title = Capitol shooting suspect was 'low-level threat' to Clinton

column1: The shooting led to the creation of the United States Capitol Police Memorial Fund, a nonprofit organization managed by the [[Capitol Police Board]] which provides funds for the families of Chestnut and Gibson.<ref>{{cite web
column5: accessdate= January 17, 2007}}</ref> In November 2005, the fund was expanded to include the family of Sgt. Christopher Eney, a USCP officer killed during a training accident in 1984.<ref>{{cite web
column7: title = Members, Capitol Police Square Off in 2006 \"Longest Yard\" Flag Football Game
column11: archivedate = January 5, 2007}}</ref> The shooting was cited as one reason for the development of the [[United States Capitol Visitor Center
column12: Capitol Visitors Center]]. The legislation authorizing the construction of the facility was introduced by [[Washington, D.C.]] [[Delegate (United States Congress)
column13: Delegate]] [[Eleanor Holmes Norton]] and was entitled the ''Jacob Joseph Chestnut-John Michael Gibson United States Capitol Visitor Center Act of 1998''.<ref>{{cite web
column15: title = Jacob Joseph Chestnut-John Michael Gibson United States Capitol Visitor Center Act of 1998 (Introduced in House)

column2: publisher = United States House of Representatives
column5: title = Attack Stirs Interest in Visitors Center
column8: date=January 30, 1999}}</ref> The door where Weston entered was renamed in honor of the two officers, from the Document Door to the Chestnut-Gibson Memorial Door.<ref>{{cite web
column10: title = To rename the Document Door of the Capitol as the Chestnut-Gibson Memorial Door. (Introduced in Senate)

column1: On March 6, 2008, Weston filed a motion requesting a hearing on his mental status. The hearing was held on May 6 with Weston appearing via teleconference from the [[Federal Correctional Complex, Butner
column2: Federal Medical Center, Butner]] with his public defender Jane Pierce and two witnesses he selected, a psychologist and vocational rehabilitation specialist.<ref>{{cite news
column5: title= Weston unlikely to ever be tried
column12: date= May 7, 2008 }}</ref> Federal judge Earl Britt denied Weston's request to be released from the federal facility, arguing that he failed to present enough evidence that he no longer needed to be committed. During the hearing defense psychologist Holly Rogers stated that, \"sometimes there are individuals who simply do not respond to medication\", implying that Weston was not ready for release. Had Weston been released from the facility, it would have made it possible for him to be taken to Washington, D.C. to stand trial for the murders of Gibson and Chestnut.<ref name=\"Yehle 1, 18\"/>

column5: Officer Jacob Chestnut, [[United States Capitol Police

column1: Officer '''Jacob Joseph Chestnut''' (April 28, 1940 – July 24, 1998), was the first [[African American]] to [[lying in honor
column2: lie in honor]] at the Capitol. Chestnut, a retired United States Air Force veteran, is buried in [[Arlington National Cemetery]]. His funeral included a speech by President [[Bill Clinton]] and a fly-over by military jets in a [[missing man formation]]. A United States Post Office located in [[Fort Washington, Maryland]] has been renamed in his and Detective John Gibson's honor.<ref name=buried/>

column1: [[Detective]] '''John Michael Gibson''' (March 29, 1956 – July 24, 1998) was a United States Capitol Police officer assigned to the dignitary protection detail of Congressman Tom DeLay. He is buried in [[Arlington National Cemetery]] after [[lying in honor]] with Chestnut in the Capitol rotunda. Detective Gibson had served with the agency for 18 years. He was a native of [[Massachusetts]] who married the niece of Representative [[Joe Moakley]], Democrat of Massachusetts.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title = Capitol Hill slayings: The Police; Congress to Pay Tribute to Slain Officers
column8: date=July 27, 1998}}</ref> He had three children, a 17-year-old daughter and two boys, ages 15 and 14.<ref name=buried>{{cite web
column10: title = Capitol Police Officers laid to rest in Arlington National Cemetery

column1: Growing up in New England, Det. Gibson was a lifelong [[Boston Red Sox]] fan, and on August 11, 1998, his beloved team had a moment of silence in his honor prior to a game with the [[Kansas City Royals]].{{citation needed
'''Russell Eugene Weston, Jr.''' (born December 28, 1956), also known as Rusty, grew up in [[Valmeyer, Illinois
column2: Valmeyer]], [[Illinois]]. Weston attended Valmeyer High School, the only high school in a town of 900 people. Shortly after graduating from high school in 1974, Weston moved to [[Rimini, Montana]], rarely returning to Valmeyer. The only attempt his high school classmates made at inviting him to a class reunion was returned with obscenities written across it.<ref name=hospitalized>{{cite news
column4: title = Capitol Hill Slayings: The Suspect; Man Hospitalized in '96 for Ominous Letters
column7: date=July 26, 1998}}</ref> Many of Weston's Montana neighbors had disliked him, and often ignored him. They considered him to be unusual, and sometimes [[Eccentricity (behavior)
column8: eccentric]]. Weston had once thought that his neighbor was using his [[television]] [[satellite dish]] to spy on his actions and believed Navy SEALs were hiding in his cornfield.<ref name=hospitalized/>

column4: Weston's cabin next to the lower [[Tenmile Creek (Lewis and Clark County, Montana)
column5: Tenmile Creek]] in [[Montana]] following a search by the police]]

column2: paranoid schizophrenia]] six years before the shooting and spent fifty-three days in a mental hospital after threatening a Montana resident. He was released after testing as being of no danger to himself or anyone else.<ref name=access/> Eighteen months before the shooting, he moved back to Valmeyer from Montana. Once home, he was known to compulsively hack at trees which filled his back yard following the [[Great Flood of 1993
column3: Mississippi River floods of 1993]]. There was so much downed timber on his family's homestead that they had to ask him to stop cutting at trees.<ref name=access>{{cite news
column5: title = Before the Shootings, a String of Excesses
column8: date=January 30, 1999}}</ref> Two days prior to the Capitol shooting, at his grandmother's insistence to do something about nearby [[cat]]s which were becoming a nuisance, Weston shot and killed 14 cats with a single-barreled shotgun, leaving several in a bucket and burying the rest.<ref name=access/>

column1: Following the Capitol shooting, Weston was transferred to a psychiatric center at [[Butner Federal Correctional Institution]] in [[Butner, North Carolina]]. In an interview with a court-appointed psychiatrist he explained that he stormed the Capitol to prevent the United States from being annihilated by disease and legions of cannibals.<ref>{{cite news
He has never been charged with any crime due to apparent mental [[culpability
column2: inculpability]]. One contentious issue of Weston's incarceration is that of forced medication. Weston has thus far refused to take any medications voluntarily. His lawyers helped enable this, in order to protect him from the death penalty.<ref>{{cite news
column8: date=March 3, 2003}}</ref> In May 2001, a federal judge authorized doctors to treat Weston involuntarily. A panel from a federal appeals court ruled in July 2001 that Weston could be forced to take the drugs which he was forced to do for 120 days.<ref>{{cite news
column10: title = Judge Rules Capitol Gunman Can Be Forced to Take Medicine
column13: date=August 3, 2002}}</ref> He remains in the Butner facility indefinitely.{{citation needed

column1: * [http://projects.ldc.upenn.edu/TDT2000/topics/completed-research/weston-indictment.html Indictment of Russell Eugene Weston, Jr.]
* [https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-srv/national/longterm/shooting/archives2.htm \"From the Shootings to the Investigation\"], ''[[The Washington Post]]''

column3:
lain in state or honor]]
in the [[United States Capitol rotunda]]
(John Gibson and Jacob Chestnut)
