→‎Marriage:renewed broken link,safe,Eebahgum,"'''Robert de Auberville''' (de Albervilla, in Latin), of Iham (Higham, in [[Icklesham]]) and [[Iden, Sussex]], representative of a wealthy Norman family in Kent and Sussex, was a [[Justiciar#England
column2: Justiciar]] in Kent, Constable of [[Hastings Castle]], and Keeper of the Coast to King [[Henry III of England]].

column1: The de Auberville family was seated at [[Westenhanger]], near [[Stanford, Kent]].<ref>T. Philipott (with J. Philipott), ''Villare Cantianum, or, Kent Surveyed and Illustrated'' (Printed by William Godbid, London 1659), 'Stamford, Folkestone Hundred', [https://quod.lib.umich.edu/e/eebo2/A54665.0001.001/1:7.18?rgn=div2;view=fulltext p. 302]. (Umich/EEBO)</ref> William de Auberville the elder, King's Justiciar (son of Hugh de Auberville (the elder) and his wife Wynanc), married Matilda (Maud), eldest daughter of [[Ranulf de Glanville]] ([[Chief Justiciar]] of England to King [[Henry II of England
column2: Henry II]]) and his wife Bertha de Valoines.<ref>'Auberville', in J.R. Planché, ''A Corner of Kent: Or, Some Account of the Parish of Ash-next-Sandwich'' (R. Hardwicke, London 1864), [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=j9Q2AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA290#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 290-91].</ref> (Bertha's sister was the wife of Hervey Walter, and mother of Archbishop [[Hubert Walter]].) William's principal heir was his son Hugh (the younger), who inherited from him,<ref>R. Taylor, ''Index Monasticus'' (Lackington & Co., London 1821), [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=FnxPAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA93#v=onepage&q&f=false pp. 93-94].</ref> but there was also a son William and a daughter Emma.<ref>W. Dugdale, ''Monasticon Anglicanum'' new edition (James Bohn, London 1846), VI Part 2, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=hc3PxVZNZugC&pg=PA898#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 898], Langdon, Charters Nos. I and II.</ref><ref>See S.J. Bailey, 'Ranulf de Glanvill and His Children', ''The Cambridge Law Journal'' Vol. 15, No. 2 (Nov., 1957), pp. 163-182; and R. Mortimer, 'The Family of Rannulf de Glanville', ''Historical Research'' 129, 1981, pp. 1–16.</ref> Hugh de Auberville the younger, together with Robert his brother, were c. 1199-1205 witnesses to a charter of John of Eu, a son of [[John, Count of Eu]], confirming to the [[Robertsbridge Abbey
column3: Cistercian abbey of Robertsbridge]] in Sussex their tenements, liberties and customs in his fee of the [[Rape of Hastings]].<ref>''Calendar of Charters and Documents relating to the Abbey of Robertsbridge Co: Sussex preserved at Penshurst among the muniments of Lord De Lisle and Dudley'' (Private, 1872), [https://archive.org/stream/calendarofcharte00selbuoft#page/24/mode/2up pp. 24-25, no. 76].</ref> The de Auberville inheritance descended through Hugh's son William de Auberville the younger (died 1248<ref>''Close Rolls of the Reign of Henry III: 1247-1251'' (HMSO, London 1922), [https://archive.org/stream/closerollsofreig06grea#page/104/mode/2up p. 105].</ref>) to his daughter Joan, who married [[Nicholas de Crioll]].

column1: Robert de Auberville maintained connections with Robertsbridge Abbey, married the heiress of another of its patron families, and became settled at the western edge of [[Romney Marsh]]. Robertsbridge was originally founded in 1176 in the parish of [[Salehurst]] by Alvred de St. Martin, Sheriff of the Rape of Hastings, whose wife was Alice d'Aubigny, widow of John, Count of Eu.<ref>'Houses of Cistercian monks: Abbey of Robertsbridge', in W. Page (ed.), ''A History of the County of Sussex'', Vol. 2 (VCH, London 1973), [http://www.british-history.ac.uk/vch/sussex/vol2/pp71-74 pp. 71-74] (British History Online, accessed 22 October 2017).</ref> William de Auberville (the elder) was associated with the foundation or patronage of various religious houses including the Augustinian Canons Regular of [[Butley Abbey]] (1171)<ref>W. Dugdale and C. Dodsworth, ''Monastici Anglicani, Volumen Alterum, De Canonicis Regularibus Augustinianis'' (Alicia Warren, London 1661), [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=5DLvJLLKKVIC&pg=PA245#v=onepage&q&f=false pp. 245 ff.].</ref> and the [[Premonstratensians]] of [[Leiston Abbey]] (1182)<ref>Foundation charters in W. Dugdale & R. Dodsworth, ''Monasticon Anglicanum, sive Pandectae Coenobiorum'', 3 Vols (London (Savoy) 1673), III, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=oLdoFZMC8EMC&pg=PA74#v=onepage&q&f=false pp. 74-76]. (in Latin).</ref> in Suffolk, both founded by Ranulf, and by his own founding, c. 1192, of [[West Langdon Abbey]] in Kent, as from Leiston Abbey, assisted by the priors of both Suffolk houses. The Langdon foundation was confirmed by Simon de Averenches, Lord of Folkestone (died c. 1203<ref>'Nova Oblata, Kent, Michaelmas 1203', in ''The Great Roll of the Pipe for the 5th year of the reign of King John, Michaelmas, 1202-1203'', Pipe Roll Society LIV, New Series XVI, [http://www.kentarchaeology.org.uk/Research/05/1202/27.htm p. 27].</ref>) who, as his [[Fief
column2: fee-lord]], refers to \"the charter of my revered knight William de Auberville\".<ref>''Monasticon Anglicanum'', (1846 edn), VI Part 2, p. 898.</ref>

column1: [[File:Robertsbridge Abbey f.58 by Samuel Hieronymus Grimm 1783.jpg

The Sheriff of Sussex was ordered to effect full seisin of the land of \"Ihōme\" and Iden in eastern Sussex to Robert de Auberville, in the right of his wife Claricia, which had been in the keeping of Hubert Walter, in July 1205.<ref>T.D. Hardy (ed.), ''Rotuli Litterarum Clausarum in Turri Londinensi Asservati'' I: Ab anno MCCIV ad annum MCCXXIV (Commissioners, 1831), [http://www.digitale-bibliothek-mv.de/viewer/image/PPN848631250/100/ p. 42b] (Mecklenburg-Vorpommern).</ref> Claricia is identified as a daughter of Robert de Gosteling on the basis of a deed of quitclaim made by her to the priory of [[Christ Church, Canterbury]] of lands in the vicinity of [[Fairfield, Kent
column3: Appledore]], on the west side of [[Romney Marsh]], near Iden. This shows her as the wife of Robert de Auberville, who has enclosed 36 acres from the sea.<ref>The National Archives, Discovery Catalogue, item description: [http://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/details/r/0b6b4574-0f22-4cdf-8c89-1c12dde9a4de CCA-DCc-ChAnt/A/117] (Canterbury Cathedral Archives).</ref> A further reference to her in the [[Curia Regis]] rolls shows that Claricia was the granddaughter of Samson de Gestling.<ref>C.T. Flower (ed.), ''Curia Regis Rolls: 7-9 Henry III'' (HMSO 1955), [https://books.google.co.uk/books?redir_esc=y&id=nXVpAAAAMAAJ&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=Sansonem p. 325].</ref><ref>See a posting by John P. Ravilious in [https://groups.google.com/forum/#!msg/soc.genealogy.medieval/d5Eyt294wwU/lKRQOUwBN2IJ Googlegroups].</ref>

column1: Samson and Robert de Gosteling appear frequently as witnesses to the Robertsbridge Abbey deeds. William de Auberville, as justiciar, presided at an early transaction, and Hugh, alone, at another.<ref>''Charters and Documents relating to the Abbey of Robertsbridge'', p. 7, no. 23; p. 18, no. 55.</ref> Robert witnessed three other Robertsbridge charters in the Lisle muniments.<ref>''Charters and Documents relating to the Abbey of Robertsbridge'', p. 12, no. 38; p. 54, no. 170; p. 68, no. 207.</ref> Sussex Fines of 1219 reflect the dealings of Robert and Claricia with the Abbey respecting lands at [[Northiam]], [[Pett]] and [[Playden]].<ref>'Sussex Fines: 1-5 Henry III (nos. 138-171)', in L.F. Salzman (ed.), ''An Abstract of Feet of Fines For the County of Sussex'', Vol. 1: 1190-1248, Sussex Records Society (Lewes, 1903), [http://www.british-history.ac.uk/feet-of-fines-sussex/vol1/pp35-44 pp. 35-44, nos. 157, 158, 162] (British History Online, accessed 22 October 2017).</ref>

In 1210 King John took a large army to Ireland in order to suppress a revolt by the Anglo-Norman lords whom he held there in governance.<ref>D. Carpenter, ''Struggle for Mastery: The Penguin History of Britain 1066–1284'' (Penguin, London 2004), pp. 280-81.</ref> Robert de Auberville fought in Ireland in that year, and Hugh is named in the same entry.<ref>G. Paget, \"An Official, Genealogical and Heraldic Baronage of England\" (1957), 11: 1-2, citing T.D. Hardy (ed.), ''Rotuli de Liberate ac de misis et praestitis, regnante Johanne'' (Commissioners, London 1844), (12 John), [https://archive.org/stream/rotulideliberate00grea#page/218/mode/2up p. 218] (Internet Archive).</ref>
In 1215, following the sealing of [[Magna Carta]] at [[Runnymede]], Robert de Auberville was with [[William d'Aubigny (rebel)
column2: William d'Aubigny]], William de Averenches, [[Reginald de Cornhill]] (the [[High Sheriff of Kent]]), Thomas de Moletun, Osbert Giffard and a hundred others who held [[Rochester Castle]] against [[John, King of England
column3: King John]], until he besieged them there and they were captured.<ref>'The Gesta Regum with its continuation' (sub anno), in W. Stubbs (ed.), ''The Historical Works of Gervase of Canterbury'' II, [https://archive.org/stream/historicalworks00stubgoog#page/n235/mode/2up p. 110]. (Internet Archive)</ref> At this time Cecilia, widow of Simon de Averenches, sold her manor of Sutton next [[Seaford, East Sussex
column4: Seaford]] to Robertsbridge,<ref>''Charters of the Abbey of Robertsbridge'', pp. 134-36 no. 368; also pp. 37-38, no. 121; p. 69, no. 208.</ref> in order to ransom her son William.

column1: Robert was however loyal to Henry III at the time of the revolt stirred up by [[William de Forz, 3rd Earl of Albemarle
column2: William de Fortibus, Earl of Aumale]], and in 1221, having been listed for the general levy of [[scutage]],<ref>''Rot. Litt. Claus.'', I, p. 475b.</ref> he was with the young king at the siege of the [[Bytham Castle
column3: Earl's castle at Bytham]] in Lincolnshire in February and March of that year. After the castle was fired a number of prisoners were taken, and on 15 March the order was given that he and Paul de Tayden should have charge of conducting them in their carts to London.<ref>''Rot. Litt. Claus.'', I, p. 453b.</ref><ref>J. Wild, ''The History of Castle Bytham, its ancient fortress and manor'' (Henry Johnson, Stamford/Houlston & Sons, London 1871), pp. 34-40, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=IlgQAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA39 at pp. 39-40].</ref>

column1: De Auberville was entrusted with a surety for the king by Rosamond, widow of Phillip de Girunde, for a fine of 20 marks to enable her to marry whom she pleased.<ref>Fine Rolls, [http://www.finerollshenry3.org.uk/content/calendar/roll_016.html#it111_006 13 February, 6 Henry III, membrane 6 no. 111] (Henry III Fine Rolls Project).</ref> In November 1222 the king paid him to buy horses for the use of [[Isabella of Scotland, Countess of Norfolk
column2: Isabella]], sister of [[Alexander II of Scotland]] when coming into his district.<ref>''Rot. Litt. Claus.'', I, p. 519b.</ref> In August 1223 his name was listed to defend the king as far as Bedford.<ref>''Rot. Litt. Claus.'', I, p. 640.</ref>

column1: In 1222 Robert appears among the witnesses to a charter, issued at Westminster, by William, son of Fulco, de [[Oudenaarde
column2: Pamele]] in favour of [[Saint Peter's Abbey, Ghent]].<ref>[[Jules de Saint-Genois]], 'Précis analytique des documents historiques, concernant les relations de l'ancien comté de Flandre avec l'Angleterre, conservés aux archives de la Flandre orientale', ''Messager des sciences historiques, ou Archives des arts et de la bibliographie de Belgique'', pp. 238-61, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=rqFMAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA256#v=onepage&q&f=false No. 19 at pp. 256-57] (Google).</ref>

column1: In 1226 Robert de Auberville and [[Henry de Sandwich]] were chosen by the king to replace justiciars in an assize in [[Canterbury]].<ref>''Cal. Patent Rolls, 1225-1232'', p. 151.</ref> He sat in an assize in [[Rochester, Kent
column2: Rochester]] with justices William de Cyriton, Simon de Chelefeld and Simon de Craye in 1228, and in 1229, with Henry de Cobham, William de Dudinton and Robert de Rokeley, at [[Greenwich]] (an assize of Mort d'Ancestor) with Henry de Sandwich, and at [[Winchelsea]] with Simon de Hechingham, William de Munceiaus and William de Oym.<ref>''Cal. Patent Rolls, 1225-1232'', pp. 212, 283, 293, 309.</ref>

column1: ==Keeper of the Coast and Constable of Hastings==
[[File:Hastings Castle and Rocks by Samuel Hieronymus Grimm 1784.jpg

From July 1225 Robert was Constable of Hastings Castle, and received regular payments for his fees and for works and operations there.<ref>(Payments): ''Calendar of Liberate Rolls, Henry III: 1226-1240'' (HMSO 1916), pp. 10, 25, 58, 78, 79, 118, 130, 164.</ref><ref>T.D. Hardy (ed.), ''Rotuli Litterarum Clausarum in Turri Londinensi Asservati'' II: Ab anno MCCXIV ad annum MCCXXVII (Commissioners, 1833), [http://www.digitale-bibliothek-mv.de/viewer/image/PPN848631404/54/ pp. 48b], 49, 55b, 64b, 90, 115b, 140. (Mecklenburg-Vorpommern)</ref> In 1226 he and brother Thomas the [[Templar]] were appointed to receive money on behalf of [[Richard, Earl of Cornwall]].<ref>''Cal. Patent Rolls, 1225-1232'', [https://archive.org/stream/patentrollsreig03lytegoog#page/n30/mode/2up p. 10].</ref> He was appointed to the position of Keeper of the Coast, then the name given to the office of [[Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports]], in 1228.<ref>''Cal. Patent Rolls, 1225-1232'', [https://archive.org/stream/patentrollsreig03lytegoog#page/n198/mode/2up p. 180].</ref> He was responsible for the general security of the ports between [[Sandwich, Kent
column2: Sandwich]] and [[Portsmouth]].<ref>K.M.E. Murray, ''The Constitutional History of the Cinque Ports'' (Manchester University Press 1935), [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=88S8AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA81#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 81].</ref> He and [[Bertram de Criol]], then [[Constable of Dover Castle]], were favoured by a writ ''de intendendo'' issued to the bailiffs and barons of the Cinque Ports in 1229:<ref>''Cal. Liberate Rolls,  1226-1240'', [https://archive.org/stream/calendaroflibera01grea#page/138/mode/2up p. 139]. ''Cal. Patent Rolls, 1225-1232'', pp. 258-59.</ref> in an equivalent writ of 1230, Henry de Sandwich appears in de Auberville's place.<ref>''Cal. Patent Rolls, 1225-1232'', p. 333.</ref>

column1: Robert witnessed a charter of confirmation to [[Hubert de Burgh]] in 1227.<ref>''Cal. Patent Rolls, 1225-1232'', p. 164.</ref> At about that time both he and Bertram de Criol also witnessed a grant to Hubert by Roger de Ware, and a companion deed of quitclaim, of land in Westminster,<ref>C.M. Burrell, H.J. Nicholson and F.N. Walsh, ''Report of the Late Important Trial in the Court of King's Bench... respecting the parochial rates claimed by the parish of St Margaret's, Westminster... 1833'' (J.B. Nichols & Son, London 1834), [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=q3sDAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA29#v=onepage&q&f=false pp. 29-30], citing Chartae Antiquae (Tower of London) Roll, K.K. Nos. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6.</ref> and also Hubert's own grant of the church of St Leonard, Alderton to the [[St. Radegund's Abbey
column2: Premonstratensian abbey of St Radegund at Bradsole]].<ref>W. Dugdale, ''Monasticon Anglicanum'' new edition (James Bohn, London 1846), VI Part 2, [https://monasticmatrix.osu.edu/sites/monasticmatrix.osu.edu/files/commentaria/primary_texts/mm-S13060-dugdalew-premonstat-bradsole.pdf pp. 939-943], at p. 942, No. X. (Monastic Matrix pdf, p. 4). Source: Cartulary of St Radegund's Abbey, Bodleian Library MSS Rawlinson B 336.</ref> In 1229 he was among the principal witnesses to the foundation charter of [[Michelham Priory]] under the hand of [[L'Aigle family
column3: Gilbert de Aquila]].<ref>L.F. Salzmann, ''The History of the Parish of Hailsham, the Abbey of Otham and the Priory of Michelham'' (Farncombe & Co, London 1901), [https://archive.org/stream/historyofparisho00salzuoft#page/n243/mode/2up pp. 199-200] (Internet Archive).</ref>

column1: In September 1229 he, with the sheriffs, received the king's command to deliver all the ships that he held in the various ports capable of carrying 16 horses to [[Portsmouth]] by the end of the month for the king's service, allowing any smaller vessels to go about their business.<ref>''Cal. Patent Rolls, 1225-1232'', p. 264.</ref> By the king's order the custody of Hastings Castle, \"which Robert de Auberville had during the king's pleasure\" was ordered to be given up by the Constable to John de Gatesden on 18 March 1230.<ref>''Cal. Patent Rolls, 1225-1232'', p. 330.</ref> In the spring of 1230 the King made his military expedition to [[Poitou]], and in May full commands were given for the defence of the ports, in which John de Gatesden had some responsibility for Shoreham, Winchelsea, Rye and Seaford, in addition to Hastings and [[Pevensey Castle
column2: Pevensey]] Castles which he as Constable was especially instructed to prepare, arm and defend. Similar instructions were given to Bertram de Criol and Henry de Sandwich as Wardens of Dover and Sandwich respectively.<ref>''Cal. Patent Rolls, 1225-1232'', [https://archive.org/stream/patentrollsreig03lytegoog#page/n382/mode/2up pp. 362-64, at p. 364].</ref>

column1: This surrender is taken by Paget to indicate that Robert had died by 1230.<ref>G. Paget, \"An Official, Genealogical and Heraldic Baronage of England\" (1957), 11: 1-2.</ref> His name disappears from the Rolls. If he died then, the date of 1245 given by [[James Robinson Planché
column2: Planché]] for a grant by William de Auberville the younger (Hugh's son) to the priory of [[Christ Church, Canterbury]], witnessed by Sir Robert de Auberville, Sir Simon de Haute (Hauth) and Sir Simon de Sandwich, begs an explanation.<ref>J.R. Planché, ''A Corner of Kent: or, some account of the parish of Ash-next-Sandwich'' (Robert Hardwicke, London 1864), [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=j9Q2AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA291#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 291], citing College of Arms MSS R.27, C.1989, 1993.</ref>

column1: Clarice, daughter and heiress of Robert de Auberville and Claricia de Gestling, married [[Fulk FitzWarin]] III (d. 1258) as his second wife. Fulk is the hero of the medieval tale of ''The History of Fulk Fitz Warin'', or ''Gesta Fulconis Filii Warini'', which survives as a 14th-century French prose version based on a lost metrical romance. In this narrative Clarice de Auberville is described as the wife of his later years, during which Fulke, having been restored to his English lands and grown very old, became blind.<ref>T. Wright (ed. and transl.), ''The History of Fulk Fitz Warine, an Outlawed Baron in the Reign of King John'', Warton Club (London 1855): [https://archive.org/details/historyoffulkfit00wriguoft/page/176/mode/2up see pp. 177-83] (Internet Archive).</ref> Both were living in 1250,<ref>Fine Rolls, [http://www.finerollshenry3.org.uk/content/calendar/roll_047.html 34 Henry III, membrane 2, no. 786]. (Henry III Fine Rolls Project).</ref> and she was the mother of Ammabil (Mabel) FitzWarin (d. 1297), who married (1) William de Crèvequer, and (2) John de Tregoz (d. c.1300). There were two daughters by the second marriage.
title=[[Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports]]

[[Category:13th-century English Navy personnel]]","'''Robert de Auberville''' (de Albervilla, in Latin), of Iham (Higham, in [[Icklesham]]) and [[Iden, Sussex]], representative of a wealthy Norman family in Kent and Sussex, was a [[Justiciar#England
column2: Justiciar]] in Kent, Constable of [[Hastings Castle]], and Keeper of the Coast to King [[Henry III of England]].

column1: The de Auberville family was seated at [[Westenhanger]], near [[Stanford, Kent]].<ref>T. Philipott (with J. Philipott), ''Villare Cantianum, or, Kent Surveyed and Illustrated'' (Printed by William Godbid, London 1659), 'Stamford, Folkestone Hundred', [https://quod.lib.umich.edu/e/eebo2/A54665.0001.001/1:7.18?rgn=div2;view=fulltext p. 302]. (Umich/EEBO)</ref> William de Auberville the elder, King's Justiciar (son of Hugh de Auberville (the elder) and his wife Wynanc), married Matilda (Maud), eldest daughter of [[Ranulf de Glanville]] ([[Chief Justiciar]] of England to King [[Henry II of England
column2: Henry II]]) and his wife Bertha de Valoines.<ref>'Auberville', in J.R. Planché, ''A Corner of Kent: Or, Some Account of the Parish of Ash-next-Sandwich'' (R. Hardwicke, London 1864), [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=j9Q2AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA290#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 290-91].</ref> (Bertha's sister was the wife of Hervey Walter, and mother of Archbishop [[Hubert Walter]].) William's principal heir was his son Hugh (the younger), who inherited from him,<ref>R. Taylor, ''Index Monasticus'' (Lackington & Co., London 1821), [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=FnxPAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA93#v=onepage&q&f=false pp. 93-94].</ref> but there was also a son William and a daughter Emma.<ref>W. Dugdale, ''Monasticon Anglicanum'' new edition (James Bohn, London 1846), VI Part 2, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=hc3PxVZNZugC&pg=PA898#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 898], Langdon, Charters Nos. I and II.</ref><ref>See S.J. Bailey, 'Ranulf de Glanvill and His Children', ''The Cambridge Law Journal'' Vol. 15, No. 2 (Nov., 1957), pp. 163-182; and R. Mortimer, 'The Family of Rannulf de Glanville', ''Historical Research'' 129, 1981, pp. 1–16.</ref> Hugh de Auberville the younger, together with Robert his brother, were c. 1199-1205 witnesses to a charter of John of Eu, a son of [[John, Count of Eu]], confirming to the [[Robertsbridge Abbey
column3: Cistercian abbey of Robertsbridge]] in Sussex their tenements, liberties and customs in his fee of the [[Rape of Hastings]].<ref>''Calendar of Charters and Documents relating to the Abbey of Robertsbridge Co: Sussex preserved at Penshurst among the muniments of Lord De Lisle and Dudley'' (Private, 1872), [https://archive.org/stream/calendarofcharte00selbuoft#page/24/mode/2up pp. 24-25, no. 76].</ref> The de Auberville inheritance descended through Hugh's son William de Auberville the younger (died 1248<ref>''Close Rolls of the Reign of Henry III: 1247-1251'' (HMSO, London 1922), [https://archive.org/stream/closerollsofreig06grea#page/104/mode/2up p. 105].</ref>) to his daughter Joan, who married [[Nicholas de Crioll]].

column1: Robert de Auberville maintained connections with Robertsbridge Abbey, married the heiress of another of its patron families, and became settled at the western edge of [[Romney Marsh]]. Robertsbridge was originally founded in 1176 in the parish of [[Salehurst]] by Alvred de St. Martin, Sheriff of the Rape of Hastings, whose wife was Alice d'Aubigny, widow of John, Count of Eu.<ref>'Houses of Cistercian monks: Abbey of Robertsbridge', in W. Page (ed.), ''A History of the County of Sussex'', Vol. 2 (VCH, London 1973), [http://www.british-history.ac.uk/vch/sussex/vol2/pp71-74 pp. 71-74] (British History Online, accessed 22 October 2017).</ref> William de Auberville (the elder) was associated with the foundation or patronage of various religious houses including the Augustinian Canons Regular of [[Butley Abbey]] (1171)<ref>W. Dugdale and C. Dodsworth, ''Monastici Anglicani, Volumen Alterum, De Canonicis Regularibus Augustinianis'' (Alicia Warren, London 1661), [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=5DLvJLLKKVIC&pg=PA245#v=onepage&q&f=false pp. 245 ff.].</ref> and the [[Premonstratensians]] of [[Leiston Abbey]] (1182)<ref>Foundation charters in W. Dugdale & R. Dodsworth, ''Monasticon Anglicanum, sive Pandectae Coenobiorum'', 3 Vols (London (Savoy) 1673), III, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=oLdoFZMC8EMC&pg=PA74#v=onepage&q&f=false pp. 74-76]. (in Latin).</ref> in Suffolk, both founded by Ranulf, and by his own founding, c. 1192, of [[West Langdon Abbey]] in Kent, as from Leiston Abbey, assisted by the priors of both Suffolk houses. The Langdon foundation was confirmed by Simon de Averenches, Lord of Folkestone (died c. 1203<ref>'Nova Oblata, Kent, Michaelmas 1203', in ''The Great Roll of the Pipe for the 5th year of the reign of King John, Michaelmas, 1202-1203'', Pipe Roll Society LIV, New Series XVI, [http://www.kentarchaeology.org.uk/Research/05/1202/27.htm p. 27].</ref>) who, as his [[Fief
column2: fee-lord]], refers to \"the charter of my revered knight William de Auberville\".<ref>''Monasticon Anglicanum'', (1846 edn), VI Part 2, p. 898.</ref>

column1: [[File:Robertsbridge Abbey f.58 by Samuel Hieronymus Grimm 1783.jpg

The Sheriff of Sussex was ordered to effect full seisin of the land of \"Ihōme\" and Iden in eastern Sussex to Robert de Auberville, in the right of his wife Claricia, which had been in the keeping of Hubert Walter, in July 1205.<ref>T.D. Hardy (ed.), ''Rotuli Litterarum Clausarum in Turri Londinensi Asservati'' I: Ab anno MCCIV ad annum MCCXXIV (Commissioners, 1831), [http://www.digitale-bibliothek-mv.de/viewer/image/PPN848631250/100/ p. 42b] (Mecklenburg-Vorpommern).</ref> Claricia is identified as a daughter of Robert de Gosteling on the basis of a deed of quitclaim made by her to the priory of [[Christ Church, Canterbury]] of lands in the vicinity of [[Fairfield, Kent
column3: Appledore]], on the west side of [[Romney Marsh]], near Iden. This shows her as the wife of Robert de Auberville, who has enclosed 36 acres from the sea.<ref>The National Archives, Discovery Catalogue, item description: [http://discovery.nationalarchives.gov.uk/details/r/0b6b4574-0f22-4cdf-8c89-1c12dde9a4de CCA-DCc-ChAnt/A/117] (Canterbury Cathedral Archives).</ref> A further reference to her in the [[Curia Regis]] rolls shows that Claricia was the granddaughter of Samson de Gestling.<ref>C.T. Flower (ed.), ''Curia Regis Rolls: 7-9 Henry III'' (HMSO 1955), [https://books.google.co.uk/books?redir_esc=y&id=nXVpAAAAMAAJ&focus=searchwithinvolume&q=Sansonem p. 325].</ref><ref>See a posting by John P. Ravilious in [http://archiver.rootsweb.ancestry.com/th/read/GEN-MEDIEVAL/2013-12/1388421761 Rootsweb].</ref>

column1: Samson and Robert de Gosteling appear frequently as witnesses to the Robertsbridge Abbey deeds. William de Auberville, as justiciar, presided at an early transaction, and Hugh, alone, at another.<ref>''Charters and Documents relating to the Abbey of Robertsbridge'', p. 7, no. 23; p. 18, no. 55.</ref> Robert witnessed three other Robertsbridge charters in the Lisle muniments.<ref>''Charters and Documents relating to the Abbey of Robertsbridge'', p. 12, no. 38; p. 54, no. 170; p. 68, no. 207.</ref> Sussex Fines of 1219 reflect the dealings of Robert and Claricia with the Abbey respecting lands at [[Northiam]], [[Pett]] and [[Playden]].<ref>'Sussex Fines: 1-5 Henry III (nos. 138-171)', in L.F. Salzman (ed.), ''An Abstract of Feet of Fines For the County of Sussex'', Vol. 1: 1190-1248, Sussex Records Society (Lewes, 1903), [http://www.british-history.ac.uk/feet-of-fines-sussex/vol1/pp35-44 pp. 35-44, nos. 157, 158, 162] (British History Online, accessed 22 October 2017).</ref>

In 1210 King John took a large army to Ireland in order to suppress a revolt by the Anglo-Norman lords whom he held there in governance.<ref>D. Carpenter, ''Struggle for Mastery: The Penguin History of Britain 1066–1284'' (Penguin, London 2004), pp. 280-81.</ref> Robert de Auberville fought in Ireland in that year, and Hugh is named in the same entry.<ref>G. Paget, \"An Official, Genealogical and Heraldic Baronage of England\" (1957), 11: 1-2, citing T.D. Hardy (ed.), ''Rotuli de Liberate ac de misis et praestitis, regnante Johanne'' (Commissioners, London 1844), (12 John), [https://archive.org/stream/rotulideliberate00grea#page/218/mode/2up p. 218] (Internet Archive).</ref>
In 1215, following the sealing of [[Magna Carta]] at [[Runnymede]], Robert de Auberville was with [[William d'Aubigny (rebel)
column2: William d'Aubigny]], William de Averenches, [[Reginald de Cornhill]] (the [[High Sheriff of Kent]]), Thomas de Moletun, Osbert Giffard and a hundred others who held [[Rochester Castle]] against [[John, King of England
column3: King John]], until he besieged them there and they were captured.<ref>'The Gesta Regum with its continuation' (sub anno), in W. Stubbs (ed.), ''The Historical Works of Gervase of Canterbury'' II, [https://archive.org/stream/historicalworks00stubgoog#page/n235/mode/2up p. 110]. (Internet Archive)</ref> At this time Cecilia, widow of Simon de Averenches, sold her manor of Sutton next [[Seaford, East Sussex
column4: Seaford]] to Robertsbridge,<ref>''Charters of the Abbey of Robertsbridge'', pp. 134-36 no. 368; also pp. 37-38, no. 121; p. 69, no. 208.</ref> in order to ransom her son William.

column1: Robert was however loyal to Henry III at the time of the revolt stirred up by [[William de Forz, 3rd Earl of Albemarle
column2: William de Fortibus, Earl of Aumale]], and in 1221, having been listed for the general levy of [[scutage]],<ref>''Rot. Litt. Claus.'', I, p. 475b.</ref> he was with the young king at the siege of the [[Bytham Castle
column3: Earl's castle at Bytham]] in Lincolnshire in February and March of that year. After the castle was fired a number of prisoners were taken, and on 15 March the order was given that he and Paul de Tayden should have charge of conducting them in their carts to London.<ref>''Rot. Litt. Claus.'', I, p. 453b.</ref><ref>J. Wild, ''The History of Castle Bytham, its ancient fortress and manor'' (Henry Johnson, Stamford/Houlston & Sons, London 1871), pp. 34-40, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=IlgQAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA39 at pp. 39-40].</ref>

column1: De Auberville was entrusted with a surety for the king by Rosamond, widow of Phillip de Girunde, for a fine of 20 marks to enable her to marry whom she pleased.<ref>Fine Rolls, [http://www.finerollshenry3.org.uk/content/calendar/roll_016.html#it111_006 13 February, 6 Henry III, membrane 6 no. 111] (Henry III Fine Rolls Project).</ref> In November 1222 the king paid him to buy horses for the use of [[Isabella of Scotland, Countess of Norfolk
column2: Isabella]], sister of [[Alexander II of Scotland]] when coming into his district.<ref>''Rot. Litt. Claus.'', I, p. 519b.</ref> In August 1223 his name was listed to defend the king as far as Bedford.<ref>''Rot. Litt. Claus.'', I, p. 640.</ref>

column1: In 1222 Robert appears among the witnesses to a charter, issued at Westminster, by William, son of Fulco, de [[Oudenaarde
column2: Pamele]] in favour of [[Saint Peter's Abbey, Ghent]].<ref>[[Jules de Saint-Genois]], 'Précis analytique des documents historiques, concernant les relations de l'ancien comté de Flandre avec l'Angleterre, conservés aux archives de la Flandre orientale', ''Messager des sciences historiques, ou Archives des arts et de la bibliographie de Belgique'', pp. 238-61, [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=rqFMAAAAcAAJ&pg=PA256#v=onepage&q&f=false No. 19 at pp. 256-57] (Google).</ref>

column1: In 1226 Robert de Auberville and [[Henry de Sandwich]] were chosen by the king to replace justiciars in an assize in [[Canterbury]].<ref>''Cal. Patent Rolls, 1225-1232'', p. 151.</ref> He sat in an assize in [[Rochester, Kent
column2: Rochester]] with justices William de Cyriton, Simon de Chelefeld and Simon de Craye in 1228, and in 1229, with Henry de Cobham, William de Dudinton and Robert de Rokeley, at [[Greenwich]] (an assize of Mort d'Ancestor) with Henry de Sandwich, and at [[Winchelsea]] with Simon de Hechingham, William de Munceiaus and William de Oym.<ref>''Cal. Patent Rolls, 1225-1232'', pp. 212, 283, 293, 309.</ref>

column1: ==Keeper of the Coast and Constable of Hastings==
[[File:Hastings Castle and Rocks by Samuel Hieronymus Grimm 1784.jpg

From July 1225 Robert was Constable of Hastings Castle, and received regular payments for his fees and for works and operations there.<ref>(Payments): ''Calendar of Liberate Rolls, Henry III: 1226-1240'' (HMSO 1916), pp. 10, 25, 58, 78, 79, 118, 130, 164.</ref><ref>T.D. Hardy (ed.), ''Rotuli Litterarum Clausarum in Turri Londinensi Asservati'' II: Ab anno MCCXIV ad annum MCCXXVII (Commissioners, 1833), [http://www.digitale-bibliothek-mv.de/viewer/image/PPN848631404/54/ pp. 48b], 49, 55b, 64b, 90, 115b, 140. (Mecklenburg-Vorpommern)</ref> In 1226 he and brother Thomas the [[Templar]] were appointed to receive money on behalf of [[Richard, Earl of Cornwall]].<ref>''Cal. Patent Rolls, 1225-1232'', [https://archive.org/stream/patentrollsreig03lytegoog#page/n30/mode/2up p. 10].</ref> He was appointed to the position of Keeper of the Coast, then the name given to the office of [[Lord Warden of the Cinque Ports]], in 1228.<ref>''Cal. Patent Rolls, 1225-1232'', [https://archive.org/stream/patentrollsreig03lytegoog#page/n198/mode/2up p. 180].</ref> He was responsible for the general security of the ports between [[Sandwich, Kent
column2: Sandwich]] and [[Portsmouth]].<ref>K.M.E. Murray, ''The Constitutional History of the Cinque Ports'' (Manchester University Press 1935), [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=88S8AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA81#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 81].</ref> He and [[Bertram de Criol]], then [[Constable of Dover Castle]], were favoured by a writ ''de intendendo'' issued to the bailiffs and barons of the Cinque Ports in 1229:<ref>''Cal. Liberate Rolls,  1226-1240'', [https://archive.org/stream/calendaroflibera01grea#page/138/mode/2up p. 139]. ''Cal. Patent Rolls, 1225-1232'', pp. 258-59.</ref> in an equivalent writ of 1230, Henry de Sandwich appears in de Auberville's place.<ref>''Cal. Patent Rolls, 1225-1232'', p. 333.</ref>

column1: Robert witnessed a charter of confirmation to [[Hubert de Burgh]] in 1227.<ref>''Cal. Patent Rolls, 1225-1232'', p. 164.</ref> At about that time both he and Bertram de Criol also witnessed a grant to Hubert by Roger de Ware, and a companion deed of quitclaim, of land in Westminster,<ref>C.M. Burrell, H.J. Nicholson and F.N. Walsh, ''Report of the Late Important Trial in the Court of King's Bench... respecting the parochial rates claimed by the parish of St Margaret's, Westminster... 1833'' (J.B. Nichols & Son, London 1834), [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=q3sDAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA29#v=onepage&q&f=false pp. 29-30], citing Chartae Antiquae (Tower of London) Roll, K.K. Nos. 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6.</ref> and also Hubert's own grant of the church of St Leonard, Alderton to the [[St. Radegund's Abbey
column2: Premonstratensian abbey of St Radegund at Bradsole]].<ref>W. Dugdale, ''Monasticon Anglicanum'' new edition (James Bohn, London 1846), VI Part 2, [https://monasticmatrix.osu.edu/sites/monasticmatrix.osu.edu/files/commentaria/primary_texts/mm-S13060-dugdalew-premonstat-bradsole.pdf pp. 939-943], at p. 942, No. X. (Monastic Matrix pdf, p. 4). Source: Cartulary of St Radegund's Abbey, Bodleian Library MSS Rawlinson B 336.</ref> In 1229 he was among the principal witnesses to the foundation charter of [[Michelham Priory]] under the hand of [[L'Aigle family
column3: Gilbert de Aquila]].<ref>L.F. Salzmann, ''The History of the Parish of Hailsham, the Abbey of Otham and the Priory of Michelham'' (Farncombe & Co, London 1901), [https://archive.org/stream/historyofparisho00salzuoft#page/n243/mode/2up pp. 199-200] (Internet Archive).</ref>

column1: In September 1229 he, with the sheriffs, received the king's command to deliver all the ships that he held in the various ports capable of carrying 16 horses to [[Portsmouth]] by the end of the month for the king's service, allowing any smaller vessels to go about their business.<ref>''Cal. Patent Rolls, 1225-1232'', p. 264.</ref> By the king's order the custody of Hastings Castle, \"which Robert de Auberville had during the king's pleasure\" was ordered to be given up by the Constable to John de Gatesden on 18 March 1230.<ref>''Cal. Patent Rolls, 1225-1232'', p. 330.</ref> In the spring of 1230 the King made his military expedition to [[Poitou]], and in May full commands were given for the defence of the ports, in which John de Gatesden had some responsibility for Shoreham, Winchelsea, Rye and Seaford, in addition to Hastings and [[Pevensey Castle
column2: Pevensey]] Castles which he as Constable was especially instructed to prepare, arm and defend. Similar instructions were given to Bertram de Criol and Henry de Sandwich as Wardens of Dover and Sandwich respectively.<ref>''Cal. Patent Rolls, 1225-1232'', [https://archive.org/stream/patentrollsreig03lytegoog#page/n382/mode/2up pp. 362-64, at p. 364].</ref>

column1: This surrender is taken by Paget to indicate that Robert had died by 1230.<ref>G. Paget, \"An Official, Genealogical and Heraldic Baronage of England\" (1957), 11: 1-2.</ref> His name disappears from the Rolls. If he died then, the date of 1245 given by [[James Robinson Planché
column2: Planché]] for a grant by William de Auberville the younger (Hugh's son) to the priory of [[Christ Church, Canterbury]], witnessed by Sir Robert de Auberville, Sir Simon de Haute (Hauth) and Sir Simon de Sandwich, begs an explanation.<ref>J.R. Planché, ''A Corner of Kent: or, some account of the parish of Ash-next-Sandwich'' (Robert Hardwicke, London 1864), [https://books.google.co.uk/books?id=j9Q2AQAAMAAJ&pg=PA291#v=onepage&q&f=false p. 291], citing College of Arms MSS R.27, C.1989, 1993.</ref>

column1: Clarice, daughter and heiress of Robert de Auberville and Claricia de Gestling, married [[Fulk FitzWarin]] III (d. 1258) as his second wife. Fulk is the hero of the medieval tale of ''The History of Fulk Fitz Warin'', or ''Gesta Fulconis Filii Warini'', which survives as a 14th-century French prose version based on a lost metrical romance. In this narrative Clarice de Auberville is described as the wife of his later years, during which Fulke, having been restored to his English lands and grown very old, became blind.<ref>T. Wright (ed. and transl.), ''The History of Fulk Fitz Warine, an Outlawed Baron in the Reign of King John'', Warton Club (London 1855): [https://archive.org/details/historyoffulkfit00wriguoft/page/176/mode/2up see pp. 177-83] (Internet Archive).</ref> Both were living in 1250,<ref>Fine Rolls, [http://www.finerollshenry3.org.uk/content/calendar/roll_047.html 34 Henry III, membrane 2, no. 786]. (Henry III Fine Rolls Project).</ref> and she was the mother of Ammabil (Mabel) FitzWarin (d. 1297), who married (1) William de Crèvequer, and (2) John de Tregoz (d. c.1300). There were two daughters by the second marriage.

column2: CBE]] (born 10 April 1955) is an English [[soprano singer]], musician, broadcaster and media personality.  She is noted for being at home in opera and \"[[crossover music]]\".<ref name=\"bbc\">{{cite web
column4: title=UK | Lesley Garrett: Doncaster's own diva

column1: Garrett was born in the town of [[Thorne, South Yorkshire
column2: Thorne]], near Doncaster, South Yorkshire into a musical family. She attended Thorne Fieldside Infant and Junior Schools and [[Thorne Grammar School]], where she performed in school plays and musicals and passed 10 [[GCE Ordinary Level
column4: A-level]] in music.<ref>''[[Daily Mail]]'' Weekend Interview. 12 May 2012, p6</ref> As she grew up she inherited her family's love of music. Her grandfather Colin Wall was a classical pianist; her father Derek worked as a railway signalman and then as a schoolteacher at Hatfield Woodhouse Primary School, eventually going on to become a headmaster. They lived nearby just south of the village; her mother Margaret (née Wall) was a talented singing seamstress and became the school secretary at Lesley's primary school. She has two sisters, Jill and Kay, one step-sister, Louise, and two step-brothers named Robert and Nicholas. At the age of 17 Garrett washed dishes at the officers' mess at nearby [[RAF Lindholme]] as a summer job.<ref name=\"Dishes\">{{cite web
column10: accessdate=10 August 2014}}</ref> While a student at the [[Royal Academy of Music]] she worked as a life model, something of which she is still proud.<ref>{{cite web
column14: title=This LIfe, Lesley Garrett | Get up and go

column1: Garrett has had an extensive music career. A graduate of the [[Royal Academy of Music]] and an alumna of the prestigious [[National Opera Studio]], she won the Decca Prize of the [[Kathleen Ferrier Award]] in 1979, thereby launching her career.<ref>{{cite web

column2: title = The Kathleen Ferrier Awards – Winners

accessdate = 6 March 2008}}</ref> Her professional debut, in 1979, was as Amor in ''[[Orontea]]'' at the music festival in [[Batignano]]. She subsequently sang, in 1980, Alice in ''[[Le comte Ory]]'' at the [[London Coliseum]] and Dorinda in ''[[Orlando (opera)
column3: Orlando]]'' at the [[Wexford Festival]], in 1981, also at Wexford, the title role in ''[[Zaide]]'', in 1982 Sophie in ''[[Werther]]'' with [[Opera North]] and in 1984 Damigella in ''[[L'incoronazione di Poppea]]'' at [[Glyndebourne Festival Opera
column8: title = Who's Who in British Opera
column13: url = https://archive.org/details/whoswhoinbritish0000adam/page/98}}</ref> From 1984, as principal soprano at [[English National Opera]], she became well known for her performances in productions of the operas ''[[Serse]]'', ''[[The Marriage of Figaro
column14: Le Nozze di Figaro]]'', ''[[Così fan tutte]]'' ''[[Die Fledermaus]]''<ref name=\"bbc\" /> and ''[[The Mikado]]''.<ref>Rahim, Sameer. [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/culture/music/opera/9841816/The-opera-novice-The-Mikado-by-Gilbert-and-Sullivan.html \"The opera novice: ''The Mikado'' by Gilbert & Sullivan\"], ''The Telegraph'', 1 February 2013</ref>

column1: Garrett has performed across the world, in countries throughout Europe, and also the United States, Australia, Russia, [[Brazil]], Japan, [[Malaysia]], [[Taiwan]] and [[South Korea]]. She has also sung opera and pop classics with [[Bryan Ferry]], [[Eurythmics]] and [[Mick Hucknall]] to celebrate the arrival of the new century on Millennium Eve in the grounds at the [[Royal Observatory, Greenwich
column2: Royal Observatory]] and [[National Maritime Museum]].<ref name=\"Lesley Garrett on Classic FM\">{{Cite web

column1: She played the lead role of Hanna Glawari in the [[Welsh National Opera]]'s production of ''[[The Merry Widow]]'', which toured the United Kingdom in 2005. In 2006 she sang the role of Mother Abbess in [[Andrew Lloyd Webber]]'s revival of ''[[The Sound of Music#2006 London revival
column2: The Sound of Music]]''. In 2008, she joined the cast of ''[[Carousel (musical)
column3: Carousel]]'' as Nettie Fowler. The production toured the UK and then transferred to the West End's [[Savoy Theatre]]. In 2013 she returned to opera with the [[monodrama]] ''[[La Voix humaine]]'' for [[Opera North]].

column1: She created the role of Val in ''Pleasure'', the first opera by [[Mark Simpson (clarinetist)
column2: Mark Simpson]], directed by [[Tim Albery]] and premiered at the Howard Assembly Room by Opera North, in April 2016.<ref>Martin Dreyer. Report from Leeds. ''[[Opera (magazine)

column1: Garrett is a member of the board of the [[English National Opera]] and a vice president of [[Harrogate International Festivals]].
In 2002 Garrett was appointed a [[Order of the British Empire
column2: CBE]] for her services to music. She was also awarded with a [[BASCA]] Gold Badge Award in October 2010, in recognition of her contribution to music.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Gold Badges For Heather Small, John Paul Jones

column1: Garrett has performed at several [[FA Cup Final]]s, including the [[2000 FA Cup Final
column2: 2000 Final]], the last to be held at the old [[Wembley Stadium (1923)
column3: Wembley Stadium]],<ref name=bbc/> the [[2007 FA Cup Final
column4: 2007 final]] held at the new [[Wembley Stadium]] (alongside [[Sarah Brightman]]), and the [[2008 FA Cup Final

column1: She also sang [[God Save the Queen
column2: the British national anthem]] on the [[Champs-Élysées]] in Paris in 2012 after [[Bradley Wiggins]] became the first Briton to win the [[Tour de France]], though her performance was not universally appreciated.<ref>{{cite news
column3: title=Lesley Garrett's ghastly rendition of the National Anthem at Tour de France ceremony

column1: In 2004, Garrett was one of the participants in the first series of the celebrity talent contest ''[[Strictly Come Dancing]]''; she and her dance partner [[Anton du Beke]] finished third. In the same year she took part in the BBC's ''[[Who Do You Think You Are? (UK TV series)
column2: Who Do You Think You Are?]]'', a [[genealogy]] documentary series, in which she journeyed through her home town of [[Thorne, South Yorkshire
column3: Thorne]] in search of her family history. She was delighted to discover that the musical gene stretched far back and had run in her family for several generations.<ref name=\"wdytya LG\">{{cite episode
column4: title=Who Do You Think You Are? with Lesley Garrett

column2: series=Who Do You Think You Are?
column3: serieslink=Who Do You Think You Are? (British TV series)
column6: airdate=2004-11-30}}</ref> Garrett is a veteran of Dictionary Corner on the [[Channel 4]] game show ''[[Countdown (game show)
column7: Countdown]]'', and in June 2005 it was thought that she was to become one of the show's rotating guest hosts while [[Richard Whiteley]] was recovering from illness. After Whiteley's death, however, the plan for rotating guest hosts was abandoned and [[Des Lynam]] took the role for the next fifteen months. Garrett did not appear on Countdown again until October 2009.

column1: On Christmas Day 2004, [[BBC Two]] broadcast ''Lesley Garrett – Music from the Movies'', co-starring her with [[Ruthie Henshall]], [[Michael McCarthy (singer)
column2: Michael McCarthy]] with the backing of the [[Opera North]] orchestra.<ref name=Christmas_2004>{{cite web
column3: title=Lesley Garrett – Music from the Movies
column15: url=http://ukchristmastv.weebly.com/bbc-2004.html}}</ref> The programme was recorded at the ''Opera In The Park'' concert which had taken place in the grounds of [[Temple Newsam]], West Yorkshire on 19 July 2003.<ref name=Garrett>{{cite AV media notes
column16: title=Lesley Garrett – Music from the Movies

column1: In February 2005, Garrett was selected to be one of the judges for BBC's ''[[Comic Relief does Fame Academy]]'', and in May she hosted and sang at the 2005 [[Classical BRIT Awards]] at the [[Royal Albert Hall]] on ITV. She was a regular panellist on the [[ITV (TV network)
column3: daytime show]] ''[[Loose Women]]'' during 2006; she featured there again in 2009 and 2010, before returning in May 2014. Garrett also appeared on ''[[This Morning (TV programme)
column4: This Morning]]'' and ''Loose Women'' in 2007, to perform a song from her latest album ''When I Fall in Love''. She also continued the post as a judge on ''Comic Relief Does Fame Academy'' in 2007.<ref>[http://www.thestage.co.uk/podcasts/2007/02/lesley_garrett_podcast_transcript.php ] {{webarchive
column6: date=13 March 2007}}</ref> She currently presents a show on the British [[European classical music

column1: From February 2008 Garrett presented the show ''Lesley Garrett's 20 Operas to See Before You Die'' on ''[[Sky Arts]]''.<ref>[http://www.skyarts.co.uk/SkyArts/Opera/Article.aspx?artid=5315]  {{webarchive

Over four weeks, beginning on 30 November 2008, she presented the Sunday morning BBC1 programme ''Christmas Voices''.<ref>[https://www.bbc.co.uk/religion/programmes/advent/christmasvoices.shtml] {{webarchive
In November 2010 she joined a long line of panellists on Five's ''[[The Wright Stuff]]''.

column2: Larry Lamb]], Garrett presented a short BBC series entitled ''When Royals Wed'' to celebrate the [[wedding of Prince William and Catherine Middleton]] in April 2011.

column1: On 30 May 2014 she made her return to the [[ITV (TV network)
column3: daytime show]] ''[[Loose Women]]''. It was announced on the programme that she would become a regular panellist again.

column1: She featured on the TV show ''My Life on a Plate'' on 10 September 2017; chef [[Brian Turner (chef)
column2: Brian Turner]] accompanied her on a trip to key locations from her childhood in Yorkshire, where she was taught by her parents to make the most out of what was available. The chef then created two dishes that wove nostalgia and the taste of home together.

column1: Garrett married in May 1991: her husband Peter<ref>{{cite news
column4: title=Fame & Fortune: Opera singer Lesley Garrett
column8: GP]] in [[Muswell Hill]]. They have a son, Jeremy, and a daughter, Chloe. The family lives in [[north London]].

column1: Garrett featured in an episode of the BBC's popular genealogy programme, ''[[Who Do You Think You Are? (UK TV series)
column2: Who Do You Think You Are?]]'', in which she explored her family's Yorkshire origins. She found out about the musicians in her family: her maternal grandfather made a living playing the piano with a small orchestra that accompanied silent films at cinemas in and around [[Sheffield]]. A great-grandfather was a travelling musician, working across [[northern England]] in the 19th century, playing to workers in pubs and clubs. During the [[First World War]] he entertained troops on the piano.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Who Do You Think You Are?

column1: As a recording artist, Garrett has released eleven solo albums. Many of them have been successful, receiving gold and silver status. ''Soprano in Red'' received the [[Gramophone Award]] for \"Best-selling Classical Artist of the Year\". Garrett was also a featured artist on the platinum selling \"[[Perfect Day (Lou Reed song)
column2: Perfect Day]]\" single released by the [[BBC]] in aid of [[Children in Need]].<ref name=\"Lesley Garrett on Classic FM\"/>

column1: Garrett created the role of Cathy in the London studio recording of [[Bernard J. Taylor]]'s operatic version of ''[[Wuthering Heights]]'', which also featured [[Dave Willetts]], [[Bonnie Langford]] and other leading British musical theatre performers. Her rendition of \"I Belong to the Earth\" was included on two of her solo albums.

Other recordings include complete audio operas: Mozart's ''The Magic Flute'' (Papagena) conducted by [[Sir Charles Mackerras]], Mozart's ''Così fan tutte'' (Despina), also conducted by Mackerras and Yum-Yum in the audio and video recordings of the [[Jonathan Miller]] production of ''[[The Mikado]]'' from ENO, in which she played the leading soprano role, Yum-Yum. She appears on two other DVDs of complete works from English National Opera, Handel's ''Ariodante'' (Dalinda) and ''[[Xerxes (opera)
column2: Xerxes]]'' (Atalanta). In the video of the 1984 [[Glyndebourne Festival Opera
column4: L'incoronazione di Poppea]]'' under [[Raymond Leppard]], she sings Nutrice and Valletto.

column1: *''I Will Wait For You'' (2000) – UK No. 28
*''When I Fall in Love'' (2007) – UK No. 11
<small>* Reprint of ''Notes From a Small Soprano'' with few edits. Also the title of some copies of the audiobook.</small>
*[https://web.archive.org/web/20070202022154/http://www.theatre.com/ask_a_star/id/3004458 2006 article on Lesley Garrett on Theatre.com]

column2: image2 = Zakynthos Airport, New Terminal, Greece 02.jpg
pushpin_map_caption = Location of airport in Greece
footnotes = Runway<ref>Jeppesen aerodrome charts</ref> Statistics<ref name=ZAKSTAT>{{cite web

column3: LGZA}} is an airport in [[Zakynthos]], Greece.

column1: In December 2015 the privatisation of Zakynthos International Airport and 13 other regional airports of Greece was finalised with the signing of the agreement between the [[Fraport#
column2: Fraport AG]]/Copelouzos Group joint venture and the state privatisation fund.<ref>{{cite web
column4: title=Greece signs privatization of 14 regional airports with Germany's Fraport - TornosNews.gr
column6: accessdate=4 May 2017}}</ref> \"We signed the deal today,\" the head of Greece's privatisation agency [[HRADF]], Stergios Pitsiorlas, told Reuters.<ref>{{cite web
column8: title=REFILE-UPDATE 1-Greece signs major privatisation deal with Germany's Fraport
column12: accessdate=4 May 2017}}</ref> According to the agreement, the joint venture will operate the 14 airports (including Zakynthos International Airport) for 40 years from 11 April 2017.<ref>{{cite web
column14: title=Fraport Greece Begins 40-Year Concession at 14 Greek Regional Airports - Fraport Greece

column1: The airport is close to the town and beach of [[Kalamaki, Zakynthos
column2: Kalamaki]]. Kalamaki beach is part of the [[National Marine Park of Zakynthos]]. The endangered loggerhead sea turtles (''[[Caretta caretta]]'') lay their eggs at the beaches of the marine park at night during the summer months. This has resulted in aircraft movement restrictions. Flights are not permitted to take off or land between 10:00PM to 5:00AM. It is at the jurisdiction of the Greek authorities to allow aircraft movements at night under extenuating circumstances. The airport opened in 1972.<ref>http://www.alxd.gr/AirportGuide/zakinthos/zakinthosE.html{{dead link
column5: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> An expansion of the airport's apron area to 35,100 m² was completed in 2003, and a new 22,150 m² terminal building was completed in 2008. The airport is 4.3 km from [[Zakynthos]] town and other seaside tourist destinations such as [[Laganas]], [[Tsilivi]] and [[Kalamaki, Zakynthos
column6: Kalamaki]]. The main approach into the airport is Runway 34. Aircraft usually have to fly over [[Laganas]] bay and make a 180-degree turn, before their final approach over sunbathing tourists on the busy [[Kalamaki, Zakynthos

column1: == Future of the Airport - Fraport Greece’s investment plan ==

On 22 March 2017, Fraport-Greece presented its master plan for the 14 regional airports, including the Zakynthos International Airport.<ref>[http://www.fraport-greece.com/eng/media-center/news/fraport-greeces-development-plan-for-the-new-era-at-the-greek-regional-airports \"Fraport Greece’s Development Plan for the New Era at the Greek Regional Airports\"], fraport-greece.com</ref>
Immediate actions that will be implemented at the airports as soon as Fraport Greece takes over operations, before the launch of the 2017 Summer season include:
• Enhancing services and offering new free Internet connection (WiFi)
• Implementing works to improve fire safety in all the areas of the airports
The following summarizes the enhancement changes that will be implemented for Zakynthos International Airport, under Fraport Greece’s investment plan, by 2021:
• 33 percent increase in check-in counters (from 15 to 20)
• 150 percent increase in the number of security-check lanes (from 2 to 5)

column1: In December 2015 the privatisation of Zakynthos International Airport and 13 other regional airports of Greece was finalised with the signing of the agreement between the [[Fraport#
column2: Fraport AG]]/Copelouzos Group joint venture and the state privatisation fund.<ref>{{cite web

column12: accessdate=4 May 2017}}</ref> According to the agreement, the joint venture will operate the 14 airports (including Zakynthos International Airport) for 40 years from 11 April 2017.<ref>{{cite web
column14: title=Fraport Greece Begins 40-Year Concession at 14 Greek Regional Airports - Fraport Greece

column1: The airport is close to the town and beach of [[Kalamaki, Zakynthos
column2: Kalamaki]]. Kalamaki beach is part of the [[National Marine Park of Zakynthos]]. The endangered loggerhead sea turtles (''[[Caretta caretta]]'') lay their eggs at the beaches of the marine park at night during the summer months. This has resulted in aircraft movement restrictions. Flights are not permitted to take off or land between 10:00PM to 5:00AM. It is at the jurisdiction of the Greek authorities to allow aircraft movements at night under extenuating circumstances. The airport opened in 1972.<ref>http://www.alxd.gr/AirportGuide/zakinthos/zakinthosE.html{{dead link
column5: fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> An expansion of the airport's apron area to 35,100 m² was completed in 2003, and a new 22,150 m² terminal building was completed in 2008. The airport is 4.3 km from [[Zakynthos]] town and other seaside tourist destinations such as [[Laganas]], [[Tsilivi]] and [[Kalamaki, Zakynthos
column6: Kalamaki]]. The main approach into the airport is Runway 34. Aircraft usually have to fly over [[Laganas]] bay and make a 180-degree turn, before their final approach over sunbathing tourists on the busy [[Kalamaki, Zakynthos
